title: Sandra May Wheeler "Sandy"
content:
Sandra May Wheeler "Sandy"

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - Sandra May Wheeler unexpectedly passed into her new world on September 24th, 2023, in Annapolis, MD with her three children by her side. Her family is deeply saddened by her sudden loss.Born on April 1, 1954, in urban Baltimore, her family moved to the scenic town of Cambridge, MD in 1962 and were captivated by the beauty of the Choptank River. Sandy attended Cambridge High School and soon after married and later happily divorced Lyle Cameron Sr., remaining amicable. She often joked that her three children were that union's greatest gift. Displaced from homemaking, like many women of her time she persevered, working at Black and Decker, Airpax, and in the hospitality industry. She also married a second time; she made it clear that his name does not merit mention in her story.Sandy was strong-willed, but also possessed immense empathy-traits that helped her though life's many challenges. She approached life with a caring and loyal spirit, leaving lasting impressions on those fortunate enough to cross her path. She loved the beach, vacations and time spent with her children and grandkids. Among her treasured memories were her childhood days spent fishing outside the Cambridge Yacht Club where her love for the water was born, and her final wish was to return to those beloved waters.In her moments of relaxation, Sandy found solace in the pages of books, immersing herself in different worlds. True crime TV shows were a guilty pleasure, and she cherished the weekends spent with her family and friends. Sandy's heart overflowed with love not only for people but also for animals. Her furry companions, both canine and feline, held a special place within her and she was as passionate about helping animals in need as she was people.Sandy is survived by her children, Donise Cameron Dukes (Greg Dukes), Sherry Cameron Adibi (Clyde Adibi), and Lyle Lewis Cameron Jr. (Dayniese Hurley) Her grandchildren, Serena Grace Bloodsworth, Violet Grace Dukes, Iris June Dukes, Joseph Koby Cameron, Scotlund Bayne Cameron, Sebastian Willey, and great-grandson Elijah Willey. She is also survived by her sisters, BJ Brown, Marion Badger, Peggy Andrews, and her brothers, John Badger and Levin Badger.A celebration of Sandy's life is planned for the 30th of September at the Cambridge Yacht Club at 1 Mill Street in Cambridge, MD, from 12 pm to 3 pm. At half past noon, a memorial service will commence. Fellowship and libations shall follow thereafter. Interment will be private.In lieu of floral arrangements, contributions may also be made to the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in tribute to Sandy's compassionate and selfless nature.

title: 'A very good friend' - Prominent Caroline leader Roger Layton dies
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'A very good friend' - Prominent Caroline leader Roger Layton dies

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Respected Caroline County leader Roger Lee Layton died Tuesday, Sept. 26, at Compass Regional Hospice in Centreville. He was 70 years old."Roger was a very good friend," said Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter, who succeeded Layton on the commission in 2010. "He was always very kind with his time and with his advice."The county flag was flown at half-staff in Layton's memory.Layton served as vice president of the commission from 2002 to 2010 and was a member of the Caroline County Board of Health during his tenure. He served on the MidShore Regional Council from 2003 to 2010 and the Caroline County Planning Commission from 2007 to 2010. He was past chair of the county Board of Estimates.The county flag was flown at half-staff in Layton's memory."I can't tell you how many conversations we had about things, and he would give me his perspective on issues," Porter said. "He was a very, very good source of information and advice, and his advice was always very good."Although he didn't know Layton well, Commission President Travis Breeding said he appreciated Layton's backing in the 2022 election."He was a supporter of mine and made sure he reached out to me and wanted a sign to put up," he said. "I heard nothing but good things about him, and obviously I have a newfound respect for his public service and the amount of time and dedication" he devoted, especially during a "second round of public service that he did as a commissioner."According to Layton's obituary, "Roger's sense of duty and commitment to public service led him to the Maryland State Police Academy, where he graduated in March 1975."He was a Maryland State trooper until his retirement in 1997 and served at barracks in Centreville, Denton, Easton, Annapolis and Salisbury.From 1997 to 2002, Layton was an investigator for the Caroline County State's Attorney Office.Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker met Layton when Layton was still a state trooper. They went on to become friends and neighbors."Roger was absolutely a great guy," Baker said. "He was a great friend and a great mentor to me, and he will be deeply missed."Born Aug. 5, 1953, in Baltimore, Layton was the son of the late Robert Cosden and the late Reva Pauline Sard. He graduated in 1972 from Easton High School."He played a pivotal role in shaping the future of his county," his obituary stated. "His dedication to his community was a testament to his love for Denton and the surrounding areas."Layton was known for his love of the outdoors, finding "solace and joy in hunting, fishing, and (excelling) in the art of trap shooting," his obituary stated."He was an avid fisherman and hunter," Breeding said. "I know firsthand after taking this position, my fishing and hunting time has suffered, so there are a lot of sacrifices that Roger made to (serve) and then to run for office a second time. It really says a lot about his dedication to the community and Caroline County."Roger devoted his time to coaching Denton Little League softball for many years and later coached in a women's softball league in Centreville.Breeding recalls a time when he was coaching with American Legion baseball and some equipment got misplaced."Roger went out of his way to make sure I got it back," he said. "He was always looking out for people. He was a good guy."In January 2006, Layton was critically injured in a fire that destroyed his home near Denton. A news report after the fire quoted then Commission President John Cole. "I have found Roger to be a man of incredible inner strength," he said. "Trusted friends with strength and dedication are hard to find."Layton is survived by his wife Faye Layton of Denton, his daughter Jaclyn Crawford (Chris) of Preston, his granddaughter Madison Weston of Denton, his stepfather Ronald Sard, his sister Rena Callahan (Bobby) of Harmony, his brother Duane Sard (Michael Anne) of Cordova; his uncle Emory Davis of Easton, his cousin Richard Davis (Kim) of Easton, his former son-in-law Mike Weston of Crapo and many nieces and nephews.In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his sister Debbie Cosden; three brothers, Michael Cosden, James H. Layton, James L. Cosden; and his aunt Mary Jane Davis.A memorial service to celebrate Layton's life will be held at noon Friday, Oct. 6, at Calvary Baptist Church in Denton, where friends may visit with the family 10:30 a.m to noon. The interment will be private. Layton's obituary can be viewed at MooreFuneralHomePA.com.In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations in memory of Roger Layton to either Compass Regional Hospice at 160 Coursevall Drive, Centreville, MD 21617, or to Calvary Baptist Church, 1120 Market St., Denton, MD 21629. 
 
 Caption: FILE PHOTO
 
ROGER LAYTON

title: Mary Harrison
content:
Mary Harrison

 EASTON - It is with great sadness that the family of Mary Harrison announces her passing at Candle Light Cove on October 7, 2023 at 99 years hold.Mary was born on Talbot Street in St.Michaels. She graduated from St. Michaels High School and Salisbury State Teachers College and then taught first grade for two years in Linthicum Heights. Even though she only taught for two years, in her heart she always considered herself to be a teacher. Mary loved reading and doing crossword puzzles, and going to the library weekly for new books to read.She married Callaway Harrison in 1946 and together they owned and operated Covington Oil Company until their retirement. Later they embraced their love of antiques, working in antique shops in St. Michaels. They then traveled the East Coast doing antique shows before opening a shop in St. Michaels. Until she became ill, she owned Antiques on Talbot with Carol Kraznowiecki and Carol Burke. There she loved meeting and talking with customers from around the world.Mary is predeceased by her parents, Norman and Ethel Marshall; son Steve Harrison; and siblings Norman Marshall and Helen Spencer.Mary is survived by her daughter and sonin-law, Marsha and Tom Waudby. She is also survived by her two cherished grandchildren and their spouses, Jenny and Jonathan Boyd and Sam and Caroline Kemp. In addition, she is survived by her great-grandchildren Charlie Callaway Kemp and Lucy Grace Boyd. She is also survived by a special niece, Susie Brady.There will be a graveside service at Olivet Cemetery in St. Michaels on Thursday, October 12 at 4:00 p.m.Mary's family would like to thank the employees of Candle Light Cove for the loving care they gave her for her last five years, as well as Talbot Hospice for making the end of her life comfortable.If you wish to donate in Mary's memory, the family suggests donations be made to Talbot Hospice, 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton, MD 21601.Share memories with the family at www.framptom.com

title: R & B Singer Rudolph Isley dies at age 84
content:

 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rudolph Isley, a founding member of the Isley Brothers who helped perform such raw rhythm and blues classics as "Shout" and "Twist and Shout" and the funky hits "That Lady" and "It's Your Thing," has died at age 84."There are no words to express my feelings and the love I have for my brother. Our family will miss him. But I know he's in a better place," Ronald Isley said in a statement released Thursday by an Isley Brothers publicist.Further details were not immediately available.A Cincinnati native, Rudolph Isley began singing in church with brothers Ronald and O'Kelly (another sibling, Vernon, died at age 13) and was still in his teens when they broke through in the late 1950s with "Shout," a secularized gospel rave that was later immortalized during the toga party scene in "Animal House." The Isleys scored again in the early 1960s with the equally spirited "Twist and Shout," which the Beatles liked so much they used it as the closing song on their debut album and opened with it for their famed 1965 concert at Shea Stadium.The Isleys' other hits included "This Old Heart of Mine (Is Weak for You)," later covered by Rod Stewart, and the Grammy-winning "It's Your Thing." In the 1970s, after younger brother Ernest and Marvin joined the group, they had even greater success with such singles as "That Lady" and "Fight the Power (Part 1)" and such million-selling albums as "The Heat Is On" and "Go for Your Guns." Rudolph Isley left the group in 1989, three years after the sudden death of O'Kelly Isley, to become a Christian minister. He was among the Isleys inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Rhonda Higginbottom (Whipple)
content:
Rhonda Higginbottom (Whipple)

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Rhonda Whipple Higginbottom, 75, of Easton, MD passed away on October 7, 2023 at the University of Maryland Hospital in Easton, MD from cardiac complications.She was surrounded by many family members including her husband, Dr. Mark Higginbottom, her three sons, wives, families, and her sister.Rhonda was born on August 31, 1948 in Avon, New York to Walton and Isabelle Whipple.After graduation from high school, she attended Syracuse University in the Nursing Program, receiving her B.S. degree in 1970. She remained at Syracuse University to receive her M.S. degree in Nursing Education, specializing in Medical-Surgical Nursing in 1972. While she was at Syracuse, she met the love of her life, Mark Higginbottom in 1967 while singing in the Chapel Choir. They were married in June of 1974 in Avon, New York and had three children: Dr. Ryan Higginbottom (Leanne), Dr. Erik Higginbottom (Melissa), and Dr. Kyle Higginbottom (Lindsey).She is survived by those families, seven grandchildren: Caroline, Lorelai, Grant, Chad, Aubrey, Miles, and Knox, a sister D. Loren Whipple from Bonita Springs Florida, and many loving cousins.Rhonda loved her nursing career and worked in many capacities to serve her patients: Charge Nurse at Bryn Mayr Hospital, Visiting Nurse outside Philadelphia, Teaching at the University of Maryland School of Nursing, Teaching at Salisbury University School of Nursing, and most recently serving as the facilitator for the Child Loss Support Group (30 years).Rhonda was a prominent figure in the development of the Child Loss Support Group and spent many hours contributing to the coordination and formation of the Child Loss Garden on Oxford Road. Her talents were many and served so many people with her wonderful ability to listen, to smile, not to pass judgement, and to give herself to the community.She loved her family and her grandchildren tremendously and would not give up any opportunity to be with them, babysit them, or to support them. They nicknamed her "Giya" and she loved them ever so dearly! Her time was spent with her family, traveling, making animals for the grandchildren, reading, gardening, and with her husband, Mark.The memorial service with be held at St.Mark's United Methodist Church on Saturday, November 4, 2023 at 1:00. Burial will be private.Any contributions you wish to make should be directed to St. Mark's United Methodist Church at 100 Peach blossom Road, Easton, MD or to the Child Loss Support Group c/o Talbot County Hospice on Cynwood Drive, Easton, MD.For online condolences, visit www.fhnfuneralhome.com

 EAST NEW MARKET - Genevieve Burton Cannon, 85, of East New Market passed away on Saturday, October 14, 2023, at her home surrounded by her loving family. She was born in Andrews on September 6, 1938, and was the daughter of the late Russell Woodrow Burton and Lucille Bradford Burton.Genevieve attended Cambridge High School and graduated with the class of 1956. On September 16, 1960, she married the love of her life, H. Rodney Cannon and just celebrated 63 years of marriage. She spent her working years in banking, insurance, and finally part time at the Board of Elections. Mrs. Cannon loved God and was a Baptist. She and her husband, Rodney, spent many years volunteering their time with the Cambridge Moose Lodge. She was a member of the Ladies of the Moose and the Eastern Star. Her greatest love was her family, spending time at her "home away from home" in Chincoteague for many years, playing cards, but most especially her grandchildren, Cody and Jordan.She is survived by her husband, Rodney Cannon, her daughter Julie Lewis and husband Fred, grandchildren Cody Lewis and Jordan Lewis, sister-in laws Anna Mae Wallace, Dinah Early, Gail McClain and husband Bob; brother-in laws Jon Cannon and wife Jean, Bill Cannon and wife Kitty, and several nieces and nephews. Besides her parents, Mrs. Cannon is preceded in death by a son, Rodney "Woody" Cannon, a sister Wanda Lee Pulley, sister-in-laws Beverly Ruark, Louise Gulick, and Harriett Wanex; brother-in laws Bryant Cannon and Frederick Cannon.A graveside service will be held on Thursday, October 19, 2023, at 2pm at Dorchester Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Coastal Hospice Foundation, P.O. Box 1733, Salisbury, MD 21802.

 SALISBURY - On October 15, 2023, Henrietta Sarah Hudson Fields Price passed away peacefully, surrounded by her children at John B. Parsons Assisted Living.Henrietta was 86.Henrietta was born in Salisbury, MD, a graduate of Wicomico High School class of 1954 and attended Salisbury State Teachers College. She had a distinguished federal government career with the United States Air Force recruiting office in Easton, MD.She married James Edward Price on July 25, 1975. James and Henrietta owned and ran Delmarva Jewelry store for over three decades in Easton, MD. Henrietta was recognized by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources for her work in providing detailed records and information collected over two decades in regards to striped bass feeding habits in the Chesapeake Bay region. For that important work, she received "Conservationist of the Year Award" in 2012 from the Coastal Conservation Association.A kind, faithful wife, mother, and grandmother, she resided just outside of Oxford, MD for over 35 years.She is survived by her sons, Gerald S. Fields (Brenda) and Brenton A. Fields (Kathleen); daughter, Lorraine E. McCool (Robert); six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.She was preceded in death by her husband, James in 2016 and granddaughter Sara in 2016.A graveside service will be held at 1:00PM on Thursday, October 19, 2023 in Belmont Cemetery, Blades Road in Preston, MD 21655.A special thank you to the staff at John B. Parsons Assisted Living Community for the loving care they provided to Henrietta.In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in Henrietta's honor to Coastal Hospice, PO Box 1733 Salisbury, MD 21802.Arrangements are in the care of Holloway Funeral Home, P.A. 501 Snow Hill Road, MD 21804.  CAMBRIDGE - The Honorable Donald F. Johnson, 80, of Cambridge peacefully went home to be with Jesus on Saturday, October 14, 2023. He was born on December 6, 1942, in Cambridge, Maryland to the late Arthur N. Johnson and Emma (Parks) Johnson Moore.Donald graduated from Cambridge High School, Class of 1960. He earned his B.S. in 1964 from Salisbury State College and his J.D. in 1969 from University of Baltimore School of Law. He was the Assistant States Attorney for Anne Arundel and Dorchester Counties from 1969-1974. Then he entered private practice until he was appointed Circuit Court Judge for Dorchester County in 1984. During his 20 years serving as the County Administrative Judge for the 1st Judicial Circuit, he was a panel chair for the Health Claims Arbitration Board and a member of the Attorney Grievance Commission. He was a past president of the Rotary Club of Cambridge and on the Board of Directors for the Dorchester General Hospital. He was a member of Grace Methodist Church, Rotary Club, Dorchester Historical Society, Barcca Class, Maryland Bar Association and Dorchester County Bar Association. He enjoyed sailing, woodworking, traveling, spending time with his family, antiquing, and visiting historical sites.He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan Shimer Johnson of Cambridge, a daughter Emmajane Olinde and husband Greg of Fruitland, a son Donald F. Johnson, Jr. and wife Amy Dukes of Wilmington, NC, three grandchildren Grace Olinde, Victoria Olinde and Mason Olinde and fiancée Brooke Planner, two brothers Wayne A. Johnson and wife Donna of Cambridge and Jeffrey L. Johnson of Salisbury, and numerous nieces and nephews.A Celebration of Life will be held on Wednesday, October 25, 2023 at 10:30am at Grace Methodist Church with Rev. Chris Pettit officiating.The family will receive friends from 9:30 to 10:30. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Grace Methodist Church, P.O. Box 815, Cambridge, MD 21613, One Mission Cambridge, P.O. Box 1495, Cambridge, MD 21613 or to the Alzheimer's Association, 909 Progress Circle Ste. 400, Salisbury, MD 21804. Arrangements are in the care of Thomas Funeral Home, P.A. in Cambridge.

 SAN DIEGO, CALIFORNIA - Elaine Jean Firestone Grollman passed away peacefully on October 25, 2023. Born in Brooklyn, NY on May 25, 1927, to Samuel and Rose Firestone. She grew up in Fitchburg MA and graduated from Fitchburg High School. She then moved to Baltimore where she went to Sinai Nursing School. She was a nurse at Sinai Hospital until 1954 when she married Julius Grollman on October 24, 1954. She moved to Stevensville and they ran Grollman's General Store together until his death in 1991. She continued to run the store until 1995 and then retired to Florida. She enjoyed traveling, reading, and visiting with family and friends.She is survived by her children, Susan Peck (Scott), Marc Grollman (Marjorie) and Lisa Davis (Tommy). Her grandchildren Brandon Davis (Jessica), Jeremy Davis (Nicole), Michael Peck (Baylee) and Stacy Davis and her great granddaughter, Josephine Davis and great grandson Weston Davis. She is also survived by many cousins, nieces and nephews. She is predeceased by her parents Samuel and Rose Firestone, her husband Julius Grollman, her brother Jerome Firestone and a granddaughter Blair Lauren Davis.Services will be at Sol Levinson's Chapel, 8900 Reisterstown Road, Pikesville, MD 21208 on Friday October 27, 2023 at 10:30am. Interment is at United Hebrew Cemetery following the service. The family will be receiving guests after the interment at Lisa Davis' house. Please see Sol Levinson's web site for address. Please omit flowers. Donations can be made to Compass Regional Hospice, 255 Comet Drive, Centreville, MD 21617 or a charity of your choice.

 CAMBRIDGE - Sharon A (Laabs) Phillips 79 of Cambridge MD passed away Wednesday October 18, 2023, at a local hospital. She was born to the late Carl and Mary (Prodell) Laabs on May 6, 1944, in Little Suamico WI.Sharon was a member of the First Baptist Church where her late husband Jay Phillips served as Deacon amongst other positions. Sharon loved her annual trips to Wisconsin with her husband Jay at Christmas time to visit and spoil her children and grandchildren until she was no longer able to make the journey. She also made the long journey to California to visit her son, daughter in-law and grandchildren as often as possible. She had a special place in her heart for all her grandchildren, especially those living in Cambridge who would visit her often. Sharon had a big heart and loved to cook for others especially sharing her delicious meals. She would cook for family, coworkers where she worked, church events, and others in her apartment complex. Sharon would always find a way to cook for others, and she would do so generously, cooking enough for her guests to take home for an extra meal.Sharon is survived by her children; Barbara Lewis of DePere, WI, Bruce (Margarita) Pantzloff of Freedom, CA, Brenda Lardnois of Green Bay, WI, Bridget (Rob) Labadie of Bell FL; 14 grandchildren, 18 great grandchildren, 1 great-great grandson; her brothers Donald (Betty) Laabs of AZ, Roy Laabs of Little Suamico WI, and Cletus Laabs of Green Bay WI.She was preceded in death by her husband Jay Phillips, son Bart Pantzloff, parents, brother Robert Laabs and sisters-in-law Evelyn and Carol Laabs.Family and friends may gather at the First Baptist Church, 501 Glenburn Ave., Cambridge MD on Friday October 27, 2023. title: Charles "Bunky" J. Bell
content:
Charles "Bunky" J. Bell

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 578
 Words 

 Read News Document

 VIENNA - Charles J. "Bunky" Bell, 80, of Vienna, passed away on October 24, 2023 at his home surrounded by his family.He was born on December 29, 1942 on the family farm in Vienna. He was the son of the late Charles A. and Catherine Jo-hannsen Bell.Bunky graduated from North Dorchester High School with the class of 1960. After graduation he enlisted in the Air Force and served four years. While in the Air Force, he learned mechanics trade and served in Thailand and Okinawa, Japan. Upon the end of his service, he went to work at A.I. Dupont in Seaford. In April of 1970 he pursued his dream and opened Bunky's Service Center LLC in Vienna, where he worked until his retirement. His son-in-law Dwaine and daughter Lori still run the business. He also worked on the family farm helping milk cows and farming and for Seller's Farm when they needed help.He loved fishing, being on the water, quail hunting, farming and being the mechanic of their Stock Car #83 and Bob Murphy was the driver.He joined Reid's Grove Methodist Church in 1952 and served on many committees. He became a member of Vienna Volunteer Fire Company in 1968, where he served twenty six consecutive years as Chief. He was awarded Member of the Year, Answered Most Fire Calls and Ambulance Calls numerous times. He was a trustee and served on many various committees. He was nominated into the Eastern Shore Hall of Fame and the Dorchester County Hall of Fame.He was also a member of Chicone Ruritan Club and served on numerous committees until they dispersed. He was also a member of American Legion Post 43 in Hurlock and VFW Post 7460 in Cambridge. He served on the Town of Vienna Board of Appeals for twenty five years and was also willing to help with whatever the town needed.On June 25, 1966 he married the love of his life, Brenda Holloway Bell. They just celebrated their 57th anniversary. He is survived by their daughter, Lori A. Bradley and husband Dwaine of Vienna, his granddaughters Taylor M. Bradley and Kaitlyn N. Bradley; a brother-in-law that they raised like a son, Kevin C. Hackett and wife Electra; his sisters Carolyn Young (late Tom Young) and Rose Murphy and husband Bob; sister-in-law Sharon Spencer; a brother-in-law(late) Greg Holloway and wife Sharon and many nieces and nephews. He was also a mentor/father figure to many that worked for him over the years.He was blessed with many caring caregivers who became part of the family; Kim, Lauren, Valarie and Vicki. He also had caring nurses when he was part of the Amedisys Home Care and Coastal Hospice Program.The family will receive friends on Sunday, October 29, 2023 from 12:00PM to 2:00PM at Reid's Grove United Methodist Church where the funeral will begin at 2:00PM. Rev. Mary Ann Farnell and Pastor Barbara Mills-Neighoff will officiate. Interment will follow in East New Market Cemetery.Dwaine Bradley, Kevin Hackett, JB Murphy, Brad Murphy, Josh Brinsfield and Samuel Abey will serve as pallbearers. Bob Murphy, Wayne Phillips, Dennis Reid, Balvin Brinsfield, Larry "Dink" Waller, Russell "Butch" Willoughby, Mark Dennis, and Reggie Sellers, Jr. will serve as honorary pallbearers.Memorial donations may be made to Reid's Grove United Methodist Church, c/o Betty Wilson, 5314 Rhodesdale-Vienna Road, Rho-desdale MD 21659 or to Vienna Volunteer Fire Department, P. O. Box 5, Vienna MD 21869.Arrangements are in the care of Zeller Funeral Home in East New Market. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: James Leo Gannon
content:
James Leo Gannon

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - James Leo Gannon, IV went home to be with the Lord on Monday, October 23, 2023. He was 39 years old.Born in Easton, Maryland, James was the son of James Leo Gannon, III and Evelyn Annette Gannon.Raised on the family farm in Cordova, James learned an appreciation for many outdoor activities and was proud of his Eastern Shore heritage. Wherever James was found, his slightly younger brother, David, and childhood friends Marc McDonald and Brian Petrichenko were usually by his side. Family always came first for James.Intimidating on the football field and the wrestling mat, but gentle in life, James touched many lives. He graduated from Easton High School in 2002 and was a member of the varsity football and wrestling teams. While in high school James was a member of the Cordova Volunteer Fire Department and served his community as an EMT. After high school James attended York College of Pennsylvania. It was there he met his new brothers in the Kappa Sigma Rho fraternity. At York College he also met the love of his life, Heather Fleischmann. The two were married in 2019. Their family grew in 2020 with the birth of their daughter, Isabella Lee Gannon. It grew again in 2022 with the birth of their second daughter, Paisley Marie Gannon.James' girls were his pride and joy. He was a loving father and devoted husband. He also found joy working alongside his father, brother, uncle, and many friends at Gannon's Refrigeration.James was a special kind of glue. He had a way of bringing people together. It brought him great pleasure to gather his fraternity brothers and close friends together twice a year to share in the beauty and camaraderie of Eastern shore living. He rejoiced in them all just being together.The Lord touched James with a full measure of faithfulness from an early age. He loved Jesus with all his heart and took great comfort in Matthew 11:30: "For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light".In addition to his parents, J.L. and Annette, James is survived by his grandmother, Donna Mckinney, his brother and family (David, Heather, Charlie, and Connor), his sister and family (Emily, Matthew, Lyla, and Sara), and countless aunts, uncles, and cousins.James was preceded in death by his grandfathers: James L. Gannon Jr. and David Ronald Mckinney, his grandmother, Eloise Wood Gannon, and his aunt Maria Gannon Nimmo.In James' words: We will "tighten up for heaven's sake".His family will host a celebration of his life on Saturday, October 28, 2023, beginning 2:00PM, at 28151 Almshouse Rd. Oxford, MD 21654.If friends wish to make a memorial donation, the family suggests donations to Matt Blue and Family at https://www.gofundme.com/f/mattblue-and-family.

title: George A. Seymour, Jr.
content:
George A. Seymour, Jr.

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9A | Section: Obituaries 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SAINT MICHAELS - George Albert Seymour, Jr. died on October 2nd of complications of pneumonia. He was predeceased by his wife of nearly 70 years, Betty Seymour, and by his son, Reverend David Seymour. He is survived by his son, Chris Seymour, and by extended family and his many friends. He was almost 97 years old.George was born November 4, 1926 in St.Michaels, Maryland, the only child of George Albert Seymour Sr. and Thelma Krill Seymour.He attended public schools in St. Michaels and in Baltimore, and then joined the army in the closing days of World War II. He served as a sergeant in the US Army Air Corps, 1st Recon Squadron, 8th Air Force, at Kadena, Okinawa, from1945 to 1946, first as an aviation mechanic, then in the Information and Education Office, where he edited a newspaper called "Recon Roundup," managed the radio station, KRW, and originated and led island history tours for squadron personnel.Returning to civilian life, George graduated cum laude with a BA in Literature from Western Maryland College in 1950, and then earned a Master of Social Work from the University of Pennsylvania in 1952. The same year, he married Betty Radcliffe, a nurse, also from St.Michaels. Their first son, David, was born in 1955, followed ten and a half months later by Chris. The family lived in Baltimore and Annapolis through the end of the 1960s, moving frequently within that area so that Dave could attend schools suited to his cerebral palsy, before returning to St. Michaels in 1971.Professionally, George served 37 years in various public and private non-profit programs in mental health, juvenile delinquency services, and other services for children. He was the Executive Director of Big Brothers of Baltimore for nine years and of Big Brothers of the National Capital Area for two years. He retired as Chief of Social Work at Eastern Shore Hospital Center, at Cambridge, Maryland, in 1987. He spent his retirement with Betty sailing, traveling, and volunteering. George served as a member of the Maryland State Board of Social Work Examiners for three years and as its chairman for one year. He was the co-founder and first president of Big Brothers/Big Sisters of the Upper Eastern Shore, and he volunteered in a variety of capacities for the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, the Talbot County Historical Society, and the St. Michaels Museum at St. Mary's Square.George not only developed the popular walking tour of sites in St. Michaels related to Frederick Douglass, he was also part of the committee that arranged for the statue of Frederick Douglas now in Easton, and he was the driving force behind the successful effort to dedicate State Route 33 to Frederick Douglass.Over the years, George earned multiple honors, including Social Worker of the Year for 1987; the Heritage Initiative Award, in 2011, for his work on Frederick Douglass' legacy; and, with Betty, the Heritage Award, in 2012, for "lifetime achievement in research and documentation of local history and volunteerism." This past spring, he was able to attend the dedication of the George and Betty Seymour Room at the St. Michael's Museum. Though by then of failing health, he spent the day flirting with the docents and promising to come help at the museum if they should need anything.George did not talk very much-he was convinced that Betty was better at talking than hebut when he did speak in the last few years of his long life, his concerns were for Betty's safety and happiness and that his family be able to enjoy his legacy to them, the beautiful house on the river. He did what he had to do to make all that happen. Also, he wanted a beer and some bacon. We made that happen for him.Services will be held at Framptom Funeral Home, Ostrowski Chapel, 312 S. Talbot Street, in St. Michaels at 11 AM, Saturday, November 4th. Interment will be at Olivet Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Talbot County Hospice, 586 Cynwood Dr. Easton, Maryland, 21601, or St. Michaels Museum, PO Box 714, St. Michaels, Maryland, 21601.To share memories with the family visit www.framptom.com

 PRESTON - James A. Hurley, 91 of Preston passed away on October 27, 2023 at Compass Hospice in Centreville, MD. He was the son of the late Willie W. Hurley and Ethel McCready Hurley.Jim worked on the family farm as a young man and then served 3 years in the Army before being honorably discharged in 1955. He had worked for the H.L. Buck Candy Co. and Frito Lay before starting his own business, Hurley's Landclearing in 1976. After being in the business for 27 years, he sold the business to his son Bruce and continued to work for him for nine years before retiring.During that time, his passion was running the D-7 bulldozer. After retiring, he enjoyed gardening and could be found working in his yard at home. He was a Lifetime member of the Preston Vol. Fire Dept., Charter member of Land Improvement Contractors of America (LICA) holding several officer positions in both organizations.He is survived by his wife of the last 3 years, Kathryn Hurley; 2 sons: Bruce Hurley (Cheryl) of Hurlock and Jon Hurley of Gulfport, Mississippi; 5 granddaughters: Rebecca Williamson (JC), Nicole Hurley, Jennifer Adams (Jerry), Courtney Hurley and Natalie Jackson (Jake); 4 great-grandchildren: Kayleigh, Brantly, Logan and Porter; step-children: Suzanne Lahman (Tom), Merrill Lahman Jr., and Gary Layman (Theresa); step-grandchildren: Krystal, Ray, Jared and Leon; several nieces and nephews and extended family. Preceding him in death were 3 children: Jeff Hurley, Duane Hurley, Jenise Hurley as well as 6 brothers, 2 sisters, and wives June and Jane.Graveside services will be held on Friday November 3 at 1:00 p.m. at the Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery, 6827 East New Market Ellwood Road, Hurlock, MD.  CHESTERTOWN - Mary Ellen Robinson Clark of Chestertown, Maryland died on Saturday October 14th at Whispering Pines Assisted Living in Rock Hall. She was 78. Born on April 25, 1945, she was the daughter of the late Walter and Delma Phillips Robinson and the sister of the late Janet Robinson Cerny.Mrs. Clark was a graduate of George Washington University, earning a Bachelor's Degree in sociology. After college, she moved to Boston to start her career with Jordan Marsh as a buyer in the bridal department.After many years, she returned to MD to care for her aging parents on the family farm in Chestertown. During this time, she began her career with Kent County Public Schools.She worked as a Career Counselor for over 20 years before retiring in August of 2008.She will be remembered for her encouraging words and guidance to countless students in their career pursuits.She married her long time partner, C. Wayne Clark in 1998, and they made their home in Chestertown. He predeceased her on July 28, 2014.Mrs. Clark enjoyed serving God through her caretaking and service to friends, neighbors, and her Church. She was an organist and active participant in St. James United Methodist Church. She often volunteered her time for community events. One of Mrs.Clark's favorite pastimes was walking around town and enjoying the nature of her beloved Kent County.She is survived by her stepchildren, Dulin Clark (Crystal) and Meredith Lefort (Will), and grandchildren, Connor and Caiden Lefort and Mikala and Mikey McCracken. She is also survived by her two nephews, Steve Cerny and Dave Cerny.A Celebration of her life will be held on Monday, November 6, 2023, at 10:00 AM at St. James United Methodist Church in Worton, MD. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to a charity of your choice or perform an act of service in Mary Ellen's memory. www.fhnfuneralhome.com

title: Ruth Emma Santucci (Dietrich)
content:
Ruth Emma Santucci (Dietrich)

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - On Saturday, June 24th, 2023, in Easton, Maryland, our beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, Ruth Emma Dietrich Santucci, gently passed away at the age of 94 years old after years of declining health. Her passing was peaceful as she was comforted and held by her youngest daughter, Anne.Ruth was born on August 21st, 1928, to Annie Elmira Eckert and Nevin Emanuel Dietrich in Fleetwood, Pennsylvania. Ruth loved and cherished her sister, Agnes Breidegam and her three brothers, Ivan, Ray, and Lloyd Dietrich, who preceded her in death.After graduating from high school, Ruth attended Mansfield State Teacher's College, in Pennsylvania. A devoted student, Ruth, earned a BA in Education, with French as her minor.She completed a graduate degree at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.She was a believer in attaining education and she so enjoyed learning, especially foreign languages.She was fluent in German and French.Ruth was a teacher for several years in New Bloomfield, Pennsylvania.Ruth married the late Hubert Chester Santucci on August 22,1953, in Hershey, Pennsylvania.Upon their move to Easton, Maryland, Ruth continued teaching for several more years at St. Michaels High School. Following the births of her daughters, she focused on raising her children and supporting her husband, Hubert, as he continued his employment as principal of Easton High School, and later as Supervisor of Instruction at the Talbot County School Board.Ruth was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She always said she would "fight tigers for her daughters". She was a nurturer, a protector, and provided calm council for her family. As her husband's health declined, she was his strength. A quiet sentinel at his casket, gently placing his sleep toboggan on his head, so he wouldn't feel cold. A calm enduring presence following his death to give comfort to all the family who were grieving.Ruth was of the Depression Era. She never asked for much and was content with what she did have. She always put others feelings ahead of her own and it was most important for her to conduct herself in a ladylike manner. She never wanted to cause distress or inconvenience for anyone. A resilient lady, calm in a crisis, always lending emotional support to others.A member of St. Peter and Paul Catholic Church, Ruth had a strong faith. She did not fear death. She was confident she would be surrounded by her loved ones when she passed.Ruth is survived by her daughters, Lisa Santucci Dunphy, Amy Santucci Parrish, and Anne Kay Santucci; granddaughter, Kathryn Taylor Raver and her husband, Adam; grandson, William Chester Parrish, and his wife, Arianne; her great-grandchildren James Hubert Raver and Peyton Louis Raver; her sons-in-law, John Dunphy and Randy Parrish. Ruth will be cremated and her remains will be buried with her cherished husband, Hubert Chester Santucci, at the Eastern Shore Veteran's Cemetery.As Ruth had a love of learning and teaching, in lieu of flowers, she would have appreciated a donation to the Talbot County Free Library of Easton, Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: H. Wade Dudrow
content:
H. Wade Dudrow

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - H. Wade Dudrow, 88, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family on November 4th, 2023, at Univ. of MD Medical Center, Baltimore, MD.Wade was born in Frederick, MD on May 10th, 1935. He was a lifelong dairy and grain farmer. His family moved to Marengo Farm in 1939. After farming Diamond Back Cove his family purchased North Glenwood Farm, now Waterside Village.Wade attended Talbot Co. Schools where he was a member of the 4-H Club and FFA. He graduated from Easton High School in 1953.From 1955 - 1957, he served in the 2nd Armored Division, 57th Tank Battalion operating tanks in Germany.Wade served on many committees including ASCS Commission committee, State Sire power committee, County DHIA board, County noxious Weed Committee, Talbot Co. Farm Bureau President serving 2 terms as President, State Farm Bureau Vice President & First Vice President. Southern States board of directors and Agway Board of directors, Talbot Petroleum board, and Easton Ruritan Club.He was a life member of the Elks 1622 and VFW. He was a chartered member of St. Marks United Methodist Church serving on the board of trustees, usher, finance committee, administrative board and volunteered with many projects.When asked what were the proudest moments in his life, without hesitating he indicated his family and having won the Atlantic Rural 4-H tractor operators' contest at age 17. His score set a record that held for 30 years.In addition to his wife Janice of 66 years, Wade is survived by his children Wendy Dudrow Cadell (David), Richard Dudrow (Debbie). He was lovingly known as Pop-pop to his grandchildren, Jordan, Brooke (Josh), Jenna (Casey), Brandon (Erin), and Great Grandchildren - Colton, Caden, Bennett, Carter. In addition, he is survived by a very close brother-in-law Ronald McCarty (Mary) and survived by many nieces and nephews.Wade was preceded in death by his parents Glenn C. Dudrow and Catherine Dudrow, sister, Jane Carroll and brother, Donald Dudrow Retiring from dairy farming in 1988, he continued as a grain farmer until 2001. Needing to pursue his love of being outside and operating equipment he continued helping local farmers and his son with his lawn care business.Wade and Janice enjoyed traveling over the years with some of his favorites being a riverboat cruise from Vienna to Amsterdam, a trip to Hawaii, and Caribbean cruises with their family.More recently he enjoyed doing puzzles, reading, and driving his pickup around town.Visitations will be at Fellows, Helfenbein & Newnam Funeral Home in Easton on Sunday, November 12, 2023, from 2 - 4 pm and Monday, November 13th from 9:30 to 10:00 at St.Mark's United Methodist Church in Easton.Services will begin at 10:00, followed by Internment with military honors at Woodlawn Memorial Park.In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to St. Marks United Methodist Church, 100 Peachblossom Rd. Easton, MD 21601 or Talbot Ag & Education Center, Inc. 10659 Hiners Lane, Easton, MD 21601.For online condolences, visit www.fhnfuneralhome.com. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Florence Elizabeth Ball
content:
Florence Elizabeth Ball

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Florence Elizabeth Ball of Easton, Maryland died on Thursday, October 26, 2023, from breast cancer.She was 75.Ms. Ball was born in Trenton, NJ on January 23, 1948, to Franklin (Frank) William Cummings & Eileen Mushaw Harrison Cummings, both of whom proceeded her in death. The family (her parents having been originally from Tilghman Island), later returned to the Eastern Shore to settle in St. Michaels, Maryland, where she married William Thomas Ball, Sr.Early in her life, Ms. Ball became an accomplished professional organist. In the early 1970s, she led the adult and youth music gospel choir at the United Methodist Church in Girdletree, Maryland. In the mid to later 70s, she returned to the mid-Shore, where she played organ jazz and classic rock at Harrison's Chesapeake House on Tilghman, Island.Upon request, Ms. Ball also played the pipe organ at various churches on the Shore.Ms. Ball then pursued her Associate Degree in Architectural Drafting and Design at Chesapeake College and became an architectural draftsperson for several years. Later in life she finally settled in Easton, Maryland working for the Talbot County Planning and Zoning office, from which she retired in 2017.In addition to her husband Scott R. Reynolds, Ms. Ball is survived by her son William Thomas Ball, Jr. and his wife, Eve Zartman-Ball and by her daughter Rebecca Jo Ball. She is also survived by her sister, Helen McQuay and her husband, David McQuay and her niece and nephew, Jessica McQuay & David J. McQuay, and his wife Patti McQuay. She is also survived by four grandchildren Jeremiah Holliday, Phelicia Ball, Ismael Hernandez-Ball, and Alexandra Zartman-Ball; and two great-grandchildren Julianna Holliday, and Astro Scissum.Memorial Services will be held at the Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home in Easton, MD on Wednesday, November 15, 2023, at 12 noon. Guests are welcome to come early from 11:30 am on to interact with the family before the service begins if desired. Interment will be private.For online condolences, please visit: www.fhnfuneralhome.com

title: Patricia Ann Nemith
content:
Patricia Ann Nemith

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 562
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMDEN, DE - Patricia Ann Nemith died peacefully at home surrounded by her husband and family on November 5th, 2023.She was 85 years old.Pat was born on 7-14-1938 to Louis and Catherine Bishop of Greensboro, MD.She was an only child and grew up on the family farm in Greensboro.She graduated from Greensboro High School then traveled to Baltimore MD to attend nursing school at Lutheran Hospital. At Lutheran she worked as a medical/surgical nurse and graduated with her certificate in nursing. She would later obtain her Bachelor of Science degree in nursing from Wilmington College.Pat married the love of her life, George Nemith, of Goldsboro MD and they settled in Camden, DE to raise a family. Pat worked at Kent General hospital and Milford Memorial Hospital as the head nurse of maternity and medical/surgical. She described herself as a multifaceted nurse and thoroughly enjoyed working at the hospital.Pat began her career as a school nurse in the Caesar Rodney School District to have a work schedule that allowed her more time with her growing family. She was a nurse at Allen Frear and Mcllvaine Elementary schools for many years before her retirement. It was not uncommon to see Pat running on the field to help an injured player at CR sporting events. She was known as "the nurse". She retired from the school district with many lifelong friends and relationships that she had throughout her life.She always stated that they worked hard but had a lot of fun too.Pat was awarded as School Nurse of the Year in 1987 by the Delaware School Nursing Association.She modestly stated that "I only do what all other school nurses do" as she believed the school nurse had one of the hardest jobs in the school.In retirement, Pat enjoyed traveling with her husband and spending time with her children and grandchildren. Pat and George traveled to Hong Kong, Hungary, China, Russia, Greece, Turkey, and Spain. They enjoyed fly fishing in Montana, and hiking in Pennsylvania, Colorado, and New York. They would also spend many weeks in Stowe, Vermont. Pat also loved time with her grandchildren and showing them the tender and funny nature of their grandma and her love of butter pecan ice cream. Pat also kept up with all her relatives, friends from high school, nursing school and CR. She cherished time talking and meeting with them and would come back from lunches and dinners laughing with remembrances of fun times and the trouble they all got into. In retirement, Pat kept her nursing skills up as a volunteer with the American Lung Association and Hope Clinic. She brought a lifetime of nursing and administrative experience to those organizations and thoroughly enjoyed her time as a volunteer.She was preceded in death by her daughter, Kimberly Nemith Suarez.She is survived by her husband of 65 years, George Nemith; children, Kevin Nemith and wife Cheryl of Camden, Delaware and Chris Nemith, wife Jamie of Gulf Breeze, Florida; Grandchildren, Tara Shegogue (Kevin & Cheryl), Haliey Lyons (Kevin & Cheryl), Jullianne Nemith (Kevin & Cheryl), Benjamin Suarez (Kim), Adam Suarez (Kim), Jake Nemith (Chris) and Rachel Nemith (Chris); and great grandchildren, Colette Lyons, Cora Shegogue, Isaac Shegogue and Jarvis Gollman Jr.Mass will be held Friday, November 10, 2023, at 10 am at the Holy Cross Church in Dover, Delaware.For online condolences please visit www.fleegleandhelfenbein.com 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Joanne Newton
content:
Joanne Newton

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 238
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Joanne Hill Newton, 80, of Cambridge, MD passed away peacefully on November 6, 2023. Joanne was predeceased by her parents, William and Billie Hill. Joanne is survived by her husband, Christopher Newton, her daughter Shannon and Kevin Evans, her brother W. Gordon and Debby Hill, her nephew, Cullen Hill and several cousins all living in the Cambridge area.Prior to retirement, Joanne and her husband purchased and ran a high-end Oriental rug business in Charlotte, NC for eighteen years.Joanne and Chris sold the business and relocated back to the eastern shore to Cambridge to be closer to the family.Joanne had a full career which started in the Social Security Administration. A relocation to southern Florida led to a career in tv/radio broadcasting scheduling commercial spots.Later, Joanne landed another dream job at Smith Barney helping clients achieve their financial goals.Joanne had a keen eye for design and attention to detail. These attributes led her to pursue her interest in interior design, an interest similarly shared by her daughter. She also enjoyed antiquing and attending the local auctions.Joanne will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed.A graveside service will be held at the East New Market Cemetery on Monday, November 13 at 2pm, all are welcome. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Baywater Animal Rescue or the Kitty City Cat Rescue. Arrangements are in the care of the Thomas Funeral Home, P.A. in Cambridge.

 CHURCH HILL - Garrett Lee German of Church Hill, MD passed away on November 8, 2023.He was 91 years old.Mr. German was born in Baltimore, MD on September 16, 1932, the son of the late William Ferdinand and Fleetwood Elizabeth German. After graduating high school, he attended Johns Hopkins University in the Electrical Engineering program.On January 26, 1952, he married his childhood sweetheart, Rena Cecilia German, who preceded him in death in 2011.The couple lived in Baltimore, where Mr.German founded and operated Garrett Electric in 1960 and was a 60-year member of Washington Lodge #3 and the Scottish Rite of Baltimore County. In 1975, he and his family moved to Kent Island, where he operated Garrett German & Sons Electrical Contracting until his retirement in 1993, creating a foundation for his family. In 1997, he and his wife moved to Ocean City, MD where they greatly enjoyed the beach and the friends that became extended family. He moved back to Queen Anne's County in 2021 where he enjoyed hunting, being a part of his community, and was a self-proclaimed political analyst.He was preceded in death by his wife of 59 years, Rena German, a grandson, Michael Schwink, and son-in-law, Glenn Schwink.He is survived by his children: Theresa Coughlin (Paul) of Ocean City, MD, Patricia Schwink of Stevensville, MD, Garrett German, Jr. of Cambridge, MD, and Clark German (Tina) of Centreville, MD; grandchildren: Eric Maier, David Maier, Christopher Schwink, Tyler German, and Kallie German; great-grandchildren: Aiden Maier, Audria Maier, Kai Maier, Noah Maier, Addison Maier, Ava Maier, and Sadie Schwink.A celebration of life will be held at a later date, to be announced.In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Centreville Masonic Lodge #180 at P.O. Box 263, Centreville, MD 21617.

title: Juliette McLennan (Clagettt)"Judy"
content:
Juliette McLennan (Clagettt)"Judy"

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 779
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PORTSMOUTH - The Honorable Juliette (Judy) Clagett McLennan, 77, of Portsmouth, Rhode Island, died November 15, 2023, surrounded by family and friends.Judy was born in Washington, DC, January 7, 1946. She lived in Chevy Chase, MD; along with Newport, RI; Montreal, Quebec, Canada; Mont Tremblant, Canada; Washington, D.C. Easton, MD; and Portsmouth, R.I. No matter where she lived, she made lifelong friends and made a difference in her communities.She retired from the U.S. Government where she served as The U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women under President George H.W. Bush.She was the first to hold this post as an Ambassador.Prior to this appointment, under President Ronald Reagan, Judy was the Manager of Blair House, which serves as the President's Guest House. Judy was active in Republican politics and served at national, state and local levels in a variety of positions from 1975-2023, including the campaigns for Presidents Ford, Reagan, George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush.Judy was proud to be a Lifetime Associate of the Fraternal Order of Police. In her work at Blair House, the Secret Service enlisted her as a member. She delighted in sharing lunch with her fellow members. She wore her Ferragamo's and they wore tactical boots. They adored her as all her friends did.Throughout her life, Judy was an influential leader in charitable and civic organizations, including the American Heart Association, The Hospital for Sick Children, The Naval War College Foundation, Newport Hospital, Seaman's Church Institute of Newport RI and the Friends of the World Food Program. Her interests in internationalism led her to serve on the Board of the Belfast Children's Summer Program, President of the Committee for a New Ireland, Trustee of the Meridian House International, and a Board Member of the International Center for Research on Women.Her lifelong interest and participation in skiing and sailing led to her positions as a Board Member on the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum and as a member of the U.S. Sailing Committee for Sailors with Disabilities. She was an Associate Member of the Canadian Ski Instructors Alliance and was once a co-owner of a ski school in Canada.Judy co-founded and served as President of the C. Thomas Clagett, Jr., Memorial Clinic and Regatta for sailors with disabilities. The regatta is named after Judy's father, Tom, who was a U.S. Navy World War II veteran who learned to sail on the Chesapeake Bay.Her numerous awards and recognitions included National Women's Economic Alliance Excellence in Leadership Award 1991; Leadership Maryland, Class of 2001; and one of three awardees of the 2010 Newport Daily News Community Service Award. She received the U.S. Sailing President's Award in both 2003 and 2023. She was awarded the Wild Women of Newport County Award 2013.She was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Ida Lewis Yacht Club, Tred Avon Yacht Club, Newport Yacht Club, Clambake Club, Spouting Rock Beach Assoc., Chevy Chase Country Club, and The Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C.Her Beloved dogs have been a source of joy and love over many years. Judy was known for her many dogs who accompanied her on numerous road trips and adventures.Judy was an avid gardener and was a member of both the Talbot County, MD, Garden Club and the Newport Garden Club. She was awarded The Oatsie M. Charles Horticulture Award at The Newport Flower Show, The Newport Tree Conservancy has listed her property as the Toad Hall Arboretum.Not only was her garden a riot of color but she held an annual Tulip Party to the delight of her friends and neighbors. Her vegetable garden bore delicious fruits that Judy shared. Many a fun day was spent helping her chop and prepare jams and other delights for canning. Friends also were treated to fresh eggs as Judy built a home for her chickens.It was an apt addition to her life as so many of her friends were like her children, or her own chicks. They loved her as she loved them. Each friend had his or her own special relationship to Judy. She shared her love of life with all who knew her. Her passing has left an irreplaceable hole in the hearts of those who were fortunate enough to call her their friend.Judy is the daughter of the late C. Thomas Clagett, Jr., and Nancy Leiter Clagett. She is survived by her daughter Stephanie McLennan, son Travis McLennan, and grandson Dominic J. McLennan. Judy is also survived by her two beloved yellow Labradors, Miss Daisy and Margot.Funeral Services will be on Tuesday, December 12, 2023, at 11am at The Washington National Cathedral in Washington D.C. Donations can be made to Clagett Sailing in Portsmouth, RI. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Clyde Francis Culver
content:
Clyde Francis Culver

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 431
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE - Trappe, MD - Clyde F. Culver, 85 years of age, entered eternal life quietly on Saturday, November 25, 2023.He was the loving husband of Nadine Culver for over 63 years.Born in Salisbury, Maryland on December 10, 1937, he was the son of the late Clyde and Ruth (Brown) Culver. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his two sons, Kevin (Suzan) Culver (Sioux Falls, SD) and Steven Culver (Madison, MD); daughter-in-law, Judann Culver (Trappe, MD); grandchildren, Zachary (Samantha) Culver (Austin, TX), Brady Culver (Asheville, NC), Benjamin Culver (Baltimore, MD) and Kimberly Culver (Virginia Beach, VA); and his sister Mary Joyce Townsend (Salisbury, MD). He was preceded in death by his sister Lorraine Marvel.Clyde was a 1955 graduate of Snow Hill High School (MD). Following graduation, he earned a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland and a Master of Science degree from the University of Delaware.His 42-year career in the food industry began with Dulany Foods (Fruitland, MD) and continued with Hanover Foods (Centre Hall/Hanover, PA), Red Cheek Apple Juice Company (Fleetwood, PA), Progresso Foods (Vineland, NJ), Minot Foods (Bridgeton, NJ), and Snow's Doxsee Company (Cape May, NJ).His responsibilities included positions such as Director of Quality Control, Plant Manager, and Vice President of Operations.In addition to his work career, he volunteered for 32 years with the Coast Guard Auxiliary, both in New Jersey and Maryland.During that time, he received many honors both locally and nationally for his service including being awarded "The President's Lifetime Achievement Award" in 2016. During his time with the Coast Guard Auxiliary, he especially enjoyed conducting boat safety inspections, teaching boating safety courses to new and experienced boaters and training new Auxiliary members.Clyde retired in 2002 and returned to his beloved Eastern Shore, moving with his wife to Trappe, Maryland. He was an avid fisherman and hunter and spent much time on the water and in the woods with his family and friends. Clyde frequently had a bourbon in one hand and a cigar in the other. He loved his family and lived life to the fullest up until the very end - catching his last rock fish and shooting his last duck in late October.A memorial service will be at noon on Saturday, December 2, 2023, at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 7215 Ocean Gateway, Easton, MD. Visitation will be at 11:30AM preceding the service. In lieu of flowers, gifts of remembrance are suggested to: Coast Guard Auxiliary Association Inc, 1301 W First Street, Suite E1, Granite City, IL 62040. Designate all gifts to: Flotilla 054-21-03 in memory of Clyde Culver.

 EASTON - David James Rose (known by his friends as "The Daver") of Bethesda and Easton, Maryland, passed away on the morning of Monday, November 27, 2023, in Easton, Maryland, with his loved ones at his side.He was 53.David was born on March 28, 1970, in Washington, DC to his parents, Warren Curtis and Lynnette James Rose (nee James).David grew up in Potomac, Maryland along with his older brother, Robert Allen.David earned his Bachelor of Science degree in Media from the University of Maryland, and spent his career as a copy editor for various professional organizations, the last 20 years with The Urban Land Institute headquartered in Washington, DC.David's passions were languages and travel.He spoke 5 languages and American Sign Language, and often traveled to explore Europe and Canada.David was a regular champion of charitable organizations, including animal welfare and children's charities.David is survived by his brother, Robert Allen Rose of West Hollywood, California, his aunt Sherry Congden and extended family in West Edmenston, New York and his adoptive family of loving friends - Jeffrey Medved, Annette Theuring, Stella Martinez, Otela Griffin, Hugh Broadus, Ilo and Orrin Richardson, Nicole Clemente, Sue Schnoor and (his canine niece) Nippers.Visitation Services will be Saturday, December 2nd, 2023, from 11 A.M. - 1:00 P.M. at Fellows, Helfenbein & Newnam Funeral Home, 106 Shamrock Road, Chester, MD 21619. A Memorial Service will follow at 1:00 P.M. title: Henry Kissinger, former secretary of state, dies at 100
content:
Henry Kissinger, former secretary of state, dies at 100

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 676
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, the diplomat with the thick glasses and gravelly voice who dominated foreign policy as the United States extricated itself from Vietnam and broke down barriers with China, died Wednesday, his consulting firm said.He was 100.With his gruff yet commanding presence and behind-the-scenes manipulation of power, Kissinger exerted uncommon influence on global affairs under Presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford, earning both vilification and the Nobel Peace Prize.Decades later, his name still provoked impassioned debate over foreign policy landmarks long past.Kissinger's power grew during the turmoil of Watergate, when the politically attuned diplomat assumed a role akin to co-president to the weakened Nixon."No doubt my vanity was piqued," Kissinger later wrote of his expanding influence. "But the dominant emotion was a premonition of catastrophe."A Jewish man who fled Nazi Germany with his family in his teens, Kissinger in his later years cultivated the reputation of respected statesman, giving speeches, offering advice to Republicans and Democrats alike and managing a global consulting business.For eight restless years - first as national security adviser, later as secretary of state, and for a time in the middle holding both titles - Kissinger ranged across the breadth of major foreign policy issues. He conducted the first "shuttle diplomacy" in the quest for Middle East peace. He used secret channels to pursue ties between the United States and China, ending decades of isolation and mutual hostility.He initiated the Paris negotiations that ultimately provided a face-saving means - a "decent interval," he called it - to get the United States out of a costly war in Vietnam. Two years later, Saigon fell to the communists.And he pursued a policy of detente with the Soviet Union that led to arms control agreements and raised the possibility that the tensions of the Cold War and its nuclear threat did not have to last forever.At age 99, he was still out on tour for his book on leadership. Asked in July 2022 interview with ABC whether he wished he could take back any of his decisions, Kissinger demurred, saying: "I've been thinking about these problems all my life. It's my hobby as well as my occupation. And so the recommendations I made were the best of which I was then capable."Kissinger was a practitioner of realpolitik - using diplomacy to achieve practical objectives rather than advance lofty ideals. Supporters said his pragmatic bent served U.S. interests; critics saw a Machiavellian approach that ran counter to democratic ideals.He was castigated for authorizing telephone wiretaps of reporters and his own National Security Council staff to plug news leaks in Nixon's White House.He was denounced on college campuses for the bombing and allied invasion of Cambodia in April 1970, intended to destroy North Vietnamese supply lines to communist forces in South Vietnam.That "incursion," as Nixon and Kissinger called it, was blamed by some for contributing to Cambodia's fall into the hands of Khmer Rouge insurgents who later slaughtered some 2 million Cambodians.Pudgy and messy, Kissinger incongruously acquired a reputation as a ladies' man in the staid Nixon administration.Kissinger, who had divorced his first wife in 1964, called women "a diversion, a hobby." Jill St. John was a frequent companion.But it turned out his real love interest was Nancy Maginnes, a researcher for Nelson Rockefeller whom he married in 1974.Yet Kissinger was reviled by many Americans for his conduct of wartime diplomacy.He was still a lightning rod decades later: In 2015, an appearance by the 91-year-old Kissinger before the Senate Armed Services Committee was disrupted by protesters demanding his arrest for war crimes and calling out his actions in Southeast Asia, Chile and beyond.Heinz Alfred Kissinger was born in the Bavarian city of Fuerth on May 27, 1923, the son of a schoolteacher.His family left Nazi Germany in 1938 and settled in Manhattan, where Heinz changed his name to Henry.Kissinger had two children, Elizabeth and David, from his first marriage. 
 
 Caption: Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger speaks during a meeting with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office of the White House, Oct. 10, 2017, in Washington. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 EASTON - Charles William Kleppinger, Jr. of Easton, MD, passed away at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton on November 28, 2023.He was 93.Born July 6, 1930, in Allentown, PA, he was the son of the late Charles Kleppinger Sr. and Dorothy Heyen. He graduated from Emmaus High School in 1948. He then continued his education at Mercersburg Academy and then on to Lehigh University.Charles married his wife, Sarah Joann Beam, on January 26, 1952. They moved their family to Easton, MD on February 29, 1952, to relocate the family business, Delmarva Narrow Fabrics, onto St. Michaels Road. In the early 1960s, he left the family business to assume a position with Loyola Federal Savings and Loan. In 1973 he took a position as the Easton Branch Manager of Second National Bank and Loan, where he retired as Vice President of the corporation. His career then transitioned into real estate appraising. He was a partner to MidShore Appraisals, where he retired in 2018.Charles is survived by his five children, Charles William Kleppinger, lll (Bill) and his wife Sandy of Wittman, MD, Ret. Col. Robert Timothy Kleppinger (Tim) and his wife Robin of Chesterfield, VA, John Christopher Kleppinger (Chris) and his wife Jeanine of Easton, MD, Jody Kleppinger Moeller and her husband Ken of Rockville, MD, and Elizabeth Kleppinger Anthony (Twigg) and her husband David of Easton, MD; 13 grandchildren, Jena Kleppinger, Kristen Cornish, Meg Kleppinger, Amy Bowling, John Kleppinger, Caitlin Lane, Kory Kleppinger, Mark Porter, Todd Kleppinger, Josh Kleppinger, Michaela Kleppinger, Ryan Anthony and Sarah Anthony; 15 great-grandchildren, Jadon, Vic, Sebastian, Addison, Charlie, Amelia, Rory, Lexie, Rhiannon, Genevieve, Lincoln, Colt, Serena, Caleb, and Alaina. Along with his parents, Charles is preceded in death by his wife, Sarah Joann Kleppinger and their grandson, Charles Madison Royer Kleppinger.A funeral service will be held on Sunday, December 10, 2023, at 1pm at Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home, P.A., 200 S. title: Raymond John Ekroos "Ray"
content:
Raymond John Ekroos "Ray"

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE, MD - In remembrance of Raymond John Ekroos (Ray), who passed away quietly at his home on December 7th 2020, age 79, after a long and stoic battle with cancer. Born in Ludlow, Vermont on December 28th, 1940 to Toivo Ekroos and Jesse McMurtry Ekroos. He had five siblings: Toivo "Ted" Ekroos, Ralph Ekroos, William "Bill" Ekroos, Joseph "Joe" Ekroos and his sister Helen Counter Ekroos.He is survived by: His wife of 56 years, Mary Lois (Egeli) Ekroos, of Trappe, MD, daughter April Ekroos Carr, of Cambridge, MD, son Jon Raymond Ekroos, and grandchildren Ethan Ekroos, Alexandra (Lexi) Ekroos and Jackson Ekroos of Easton, MD; son Jeffrey S. Owen and wife Amy Owen and grandchildren Justin Owen and Jacob Owen, of Brandon VT.Ray was a longtime friend of Bill W., celebrating nearly 42 years. He made a career of helping others as an Addictions Counselor at the Talbot County Health Department's Addictions Program. He was a man who lived with simple and honest principals. He lived one day at a time and in each day, he would extract as much joy and exhilaration out of life as he possibly could, "Today is a great day to be alive" being a favorite quote of his.Ray enjoyed many hobbies including traveling, riding his motorcycle, playing pool, fishing, shopping, sailing, and car shows. He often could be seen in his small red 1983 convertible Porche Carrera with his infamous vanity tag. He especially enjoyed trips to his birth state of Vermont, riding his motorcycle through the mountain's backroads with his wife on the back.Ray is sorely missed and will live on in his family's hearts and through the community with all the lives he touched and impacted.

title: Longtime Hillsboro Commissioner Dies - Ron Stafford Served Town 36 Years
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Longtime Hillsboro Commissioner Dies - Ron Stafford Served Town 36 Years

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HILLSBORO - Ronald Stafford, longtime Hillsboro town commissioner, died Friday, Dec. 8, at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton. He was 77."Ronnie was a great guy," said Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter, a friend of Stafford for many years.
"Every time I saw him, we would talk about things involving the county," he said.
"He was always very, very supportive and never failed to say if there was anything he could do to help or anything he that he could lend his voice to, to let him know."
Porter added: "He was always very positive about everything and thanked us for serving and that type of thing."
"I really didn't know him that well, but I know he was a pillar figure in his community and will be sorely missed," Greensboro Mayor David Spencer said. "He was always very friendly to me and everyone he met."
"He played a vital role in the vitality of our Town," the Town of Hillsboro posted Dec. 11 on its Facebook page.
"His commitment and dedication to Hillsboro did not end with his Commissionership.
He will be greatly missed by all and our sympathies go out to his family."
"It's heartbreaking," Hillsboro Commission Vice President Steve Higdon said.
"He did so much for this town, it's unbelievable," Commission President Sandy Higdon said. Among Stafford's accomplishments were establishing the townowned playground and the town's latest charter. She said the town's population is only 120.
Another thing that he did when he was commissioner was (the commission) acquired the historic bank building on Main Street," Steve Higdon said. "He was behind that and so much stuff that they did."
Born in 1946 in Greensboro, Stafford was the son of the late Wesley Frederick Stafford and Elizabeth Ann Wright Stafford. He was a 1964 graduate of North Caroline High School in Ridgely.
Stafford had worked for Sheetz Construction in Baltimore before driving for UPS for 26 years, retiring in 2003.
He served in the Maryland National Guard for seven years.
"Ronnie was fond of traveling with his family and friends," according to his obituary. "He was an avid camper, a fan of the Baltimore Ravens and liked to refinish furniture. Most of all, he was a great husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, and great-grandfather.
He loved spending time with his family."
"Every time I saw him, he always had a big smile on his face," Porter said. "And I know he was a tremendous family guy, and just a very, very good guy who always had the best interests of his town and the county in mind."
Kathy Higdon said Stafford "had just had knee surgery the day before Thanksgiving," so he decorated his home on Main Street beforehand, and his Christmas lights were ready to be turned on the day after Thanksgiving.
Stafford is survived by his wife of 56 years, Peggy M. Stafford of Hillsboro; his son Larry Stafford (Melinda) of Hillsboro; his daughter Heidi Stafford Aviles (Earl) of Ridgely; his brother Dale W. Stafford Sr. of Preston; three grandchildren: Brianna Stafford (Bobby Graff), Alayna Stafford (Gus Clark) and Brendan Aviles; and two great grandchildren, Colton Graff and Parker Graff. He was preceded in death by his brother Franklin Perry and his sister Sharon Blackwell.
A visitation will be held 6 to 8 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 13, at Moore Funeral Home, 12 S. Second St., Denton. A funeral service will be held 1 p.m. Thursday, Dec. 14, at Hillsboro-Queen Anne United Methodist Church, 21991 Main St., Hillsboro.
Interment will be in Green Mount Cemetery on Cemetery Road in Hillsboro.
In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations be made in Ronald Stafford's memory to Caroline Cougars Football and Cheer, PO Box 183, Ridgely, MD 21660.
To view his obituary, visit www.moorefuneralhomepa.com. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF FACEBOOK RONALD STAFFORD

title: Thomas Hamilton Reynolds
content:
Thomas Hamilton Reynolds

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN - Thomas H. Reynolds, 77, of Queenstown, Md passed away on December 5, 2023 surrounded by family.Tom was born and raised on Maryland's Eastern shore, the son of the late Henry Clay and Rita (Aquino) Reynolds, Jr. After graduating from Centreville HS, Tom enlisted in the National Guard obtaining the rank of Sergeant. Tom later met and married his wife Donna building a beautiful life of 54 years together. He was a lifelong carpenter eventually owning and operating a successful construction business in Talbot County. He enjoyed being on the water crabbing, oystering and fishing.
In retirement, Tom had many hobbies and interests. If he wasn't on the water fishing, he was in his workshop turning chunks of found wood and various other materials into beautiful pieces of art, travelling to craft shows accompanied by his "road dogs"; his grandsons or good friends, selling his pieces and meeting other artisans. Tom frequented the local library and was an avid reader enjoying westerns, mystery and suspense novels devouring a book a day. Tom will be remembered most for his love of his family, his quick wit, sense of humor and appreciation of a good prank.
His wide smile, goofy grin and chuckle laugh will be greatly missed.
Tom is survived by his cherished wife Donna; daughters, Kathryn Adams (Larry), Karen Romano (Chris) and Kelly Stacey (Ricky); siblings; Faith Hodan, Artie Reynolds and Paul Reynolds and his beloved grandchildren; Seth, Luke, Dominic, Dylan and Mac. In addition to his parents, Tom is predeceased by his brothers; Richard 'Dick" Reynolds and Henry "Hal" Reynolds.
On Friday, December 15, 2023 visitation will be held from 10-11am followed by memorial service at 11am at Fellows, Helfenbein, & Newnam Funeral Home, Chester, MD.
Please consider a memorial contribution in memory of Tom to Compass Regional Hospice.
For online condolences go to www.fhnfuneralhome.com

 PRESTON - Robin L. Murphy of Preston, MD, passed away on Saturday, December 9, 2023, at the University of MD Medical Center in Baltimore, MD. She was 66 years old.Born in Easton, MD on May 31, 1957, Mrs. Murphy was the daughter of the late Leroy Lord of Preston and Nellie Patchett of Kuna, ID. She was a 1975 graduate of Colonel Richardson High School.
Robin dedicated her life to supporting her son Michael with Cerebral Palsey and in doing so was an advocate for many children and families with disabilities. She was a pioneer in developing services and activities that made the lives of those with disabilities better. In 1994, she was instrumental in establishing the Mid-Shore Challengers, Inc. that enabled children with disabilities to enjoy sports and social activities with their families. Her efforts to make the lives of children with disabilities better have impacted hundreds of families on the Mid Shore.
Above all else Robin was a loving wife and mother.

Murphy, II of Preston and Luke Belonga of Holmdel, NJ; a daughter, Page Murphy of Preston; a granddaughter, Alexis Tuttle of Henderson; three sisters: Hope Chaplain of Preston, Trudy Coleman of Boise, ID, and Elizabeth Sattelmaier of Kuna, ID; and step siblings: Debbie Lord Guessford of Federalsburg, and James Michael Kennedy, Sr of Preston.
