title: Gone But Not Forgotten 2023: Farewell To A 'Friend' And Others - Ontap
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Gone But Not Forgotten 2023: Farewell To A 'Friend' And Others - Ontap

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: A12 | Section: News 
 
 409
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As another calendar year ends, it's worth taking time to reflect on the television personalities who left us during the past 12 months and in 2023, they included some of the medium's most beloved talents. Here are memories of some of them.Matthew Perry: It's almost impossible to grasp any of the six "Friends" being absent now, but that happened with the passing of the actor who fit the part of witty, acerbic Chandler Bing like a glove.
Norman Lear: A much-celebrated master of socially relevant comedy, his work will live on in classic series from "All in the Family" to "One Day at a Time."
Suzanne Somers: Thanks to this actress, the lovably daft Chrissy Snow became one of the most popular female characters in sitcom history on "Three's Company."
Cindy Williams: Thanks to the half of the team she upheld, "Laverne & Shirley" boasted one of TV comedy's all-time-top duos.
David McCallum: Years after he was a pop-culture sensation as spy Illya Kuryakin on "The Man From U.N.C.L.E.," McCallum gained another audience as Dr. Donald "Ducky" Mallard on the globally popular "NCIS."
Richard Belzer: This actor and comic's portrayal of Detective John Munch on "Homicide: Life on the Street" proved impactful enough to be transferred into "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit."
Bob Barker: Though Bill Cullen hosted the original "The Price Is Right," the personable Barker made the game show his own - and for many years - when he began hosting a revival in 1972.
Len Goodman: The lovably fussy judge always enlivened "Dancing With the Stars."
Paul Reubens: In his distinctive persona as Pee-wee Herman, this comedic actor made a major contribution to the field of family programming with "Pee-wee's Playhouse."
Tony Bennett: One of popular music's most enduring talents made regular TV appearances, up to his specials with Lady Gaga in the twilight of his career.
Harry Belafonte: Among the many pursuits by this icon of entertainment and civil rights were acclaimed TV specials, some done in tandem with such other stars as Julie Andrews and Lena Horne.
Richard Moll: The tall actor who embodied the role of bailiff Bull was one of the reasons for the success of the original "Night Court."
Ron Cephas Jones: This excellent actor's moving portrayal of Randall's (Sterling K. Brown) father William on "This Is Us" earned him two Primetime Emmy Awards.
Treat Williams: This prolific actor had notable series runs on "Everwood" and "Chesapeake Shores," and recurring stints on such hits as "Chicago Fire" and "Blue Bloods." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 Page: B7 | Section: Obituaries

 Words

 LANHAM - Larry Lee O'Ferrall passed away on December 5, 2023 at the age of 84 with his family by his side. He was born near East New Market in 1939, to the late Margaret and William O'Ferrall. Larry had three brothers Franklin, William, and Daniel O'Ferrall. He attended North Dorchester High School and graduated in 1957.Larry married Helen Hurlock on August 7, 1960 in Hurlock, MD. They moved to the suburbs of Washington, DC and in 1966, they had a son, Larry Allen O'Ferrall. Larry Lee has two grandchildren, Steven and Shannon O'Ferrall.
Larry worked in the computer field for the Central Intelligence Agency from 1960 to 2005. After retiring he briefly worked for the US Army as a contractor.
Larry was an avid sports fan who played baseball and football in High School as well as softball and football with the CIA. For over a decade he played softball on the same team with his son.
He was an avid reader and interested in history.
He enjoyed crabbing and fishing in the rivers on the Eastern Shore as a youth. He was a devoted family man and a proud grandparent. He was always in attendance at his grandchildren's events and games.
Besides his wife Helen, Larry is survived by Larry Allen O'Ferrall, his daughter-in-law Elizabeth O'Ferrall, his grandchildren Steven and Shannon O'Ferrall, his sister-in-law Barbara O'Ferrall and several nieces and nephews. He is preceded in death by his parents and brothers.
A viewing and funeral service will be held at the Zeller Funeral Home in East New Market, MD on Sunday, December 17th. The viewing will be at 1 pm and service at 2 pm. The burial will follow immediately at the Unity Washington Cemetery in Hurlock.

title: Charles Henry Thornton Jr.
content:
Charles Henry Thornton Jr.

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Charles "Charlie" H. Thornton II passed away on December 12, 2023 surrounded by his family following a brief illness.Charlie, a worldrenowned structural engineer, and the founder of Thornton Tomasetti started the ACE Mentor Program in 1994, when he saw a decline in engineering enrollment at his alma mater, Manhattan College. His belief in the transformative power of education and mentoring took ACE Mentor from a single team of students in New York City to over 10,000 students a year across 70+ metro areas today. ACE Mentor Programs spread so quickly because of Charlie's intense passion for its cause.
Charlie worked with many of the most talented architects of the day and his firm amassed a portfolio of high-rise buildings, airports, sports and entertainment venues, transportation hubs and special and long-span structures, many of which have set industry standards for innovative thinking. These include some of the first supertall towers-Petronas Towers in Malaysia and Taipei 101 in Taiwan-and countless iconic structures around the world.
Between his pioneering work in structural engineering, which reshaped skylines and set new standards for innovation in the built environment, to his commitment to nurturing the next generation of professionals, Charlie's impact on this world is immeasurable.
Charlie Thornton, the proud son of a bricklayer, went on to earn his Ph.D. in Structural Engineering from NYU. He leaves behind a legacy of innovation, education, and mentorship that will endure for generations. As we mourn his loss, let us also celebrate the extraordinary life of a man whose passion and vision continue to shape our lives today.
Charlie is predeceased by his parents Charles, Sr and Evelyn. He is survived by his wife Carolyn, his daughters Diana, Kathy (Brian), Becky, and his son Charles III (Kathleen), his grandchildren Ryan (Jackie), Kaitlin (Shawn), Casey, Andrew, Brandon (Emma), Meghan (Nate), and Charles IV, and two great-grandchildren.
He is also survived by his brothers William (Joan) and Robert (Gerry).
Details regarding memorial services will be shared with friends, family, and colleagues in the coming days. In lieu of flowers, please consider continuing Charlie's legacy with a donation to the ACE Mentor Program's Charles H. Thornton Memorial Scholarship. Donations can be made online at this link, acementor.org/cht-scholarship, or mailed to ACE Mentor Program at 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, PA 19102.

 GREENSBORO - Ronald Mason Pippin passed away Monday, December 18th at Caroline Nursing Home in Denton, MD. He was 79 years old. Ronny was born in Easton, MD on February 12th, 1944.He was the son of the late William Mason Pippin and Betty Pippin of Greensboro, MD.
Ronny was a 1962 Graduate of North Caroline High School. In 1964 he enlisted in the Army National Guard, where he served for just over 33 years.
Ronny was a Test Conductor for ILC Dover in Frederica, DE from where he retired.
There, he tested space suits worn in space by the astronauts, many of whom he got to meet.
He was very proud to be part of the space program.
Ronny was a member of the Greensboro Lions Club and served on the Board of Elections for Caroline County. He was a staunch Republican and patriot. He was also a huge civil war and history buff. He loved to travel and could tell you how to get anywhere. He was also kind and funny. He had the best sense of humor and was always smiling and friendly! Most of all though, Ronny loved his family. He was especially proud of his children and grandchildren.
Ronny is survived by his wife Diane Pippin of Greensboro, MD; his daughter Tina Shulties (Larry Conley) of Hartly, DE; his son Jeff Pippin of Greensboro, MD; sister Patty Brelia (Pete) of Greensboro, MD; three grandchildren, Katey Shulties (Danny Fox); Mason Shulties, and Tristan Pippin; one great grandchild, Marshall Fox; and one niece, Lauren Brelia. He was the best Dad and Pop Pop ever!
Relatives and friends are invited to his viewing at 12 noon on Friday, December 22nd at Fleegle and Helfenbein Funeral Home, 106 W. Sunset Ave., Greensboro, MD. Funeral service will immediately follow at 1:00. Interment with military honors will follow at Greensboro Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, a Memorial Fund has been created in Ronny's memory at St. Jude Childrens Hospital.

title: Doris M. Dietz (Murcott)"Dashing Doris"
content:
Doris M. Dietz (Murcott)"Dashing Doris"

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Doris Murcott Dietz died in Easton, Maryland, on December 15, 2023 at the age of 104. She was predeceased by her parents, Edith and Harry Murcott, her beloved husband, Philip Dietz, her brother, Harry Murcott, her sister, Patricia Jensen, her daughter, Andrea Prior, her granddaughter, Michelle Wagner, her daughter-in-law, Penny Dietz, her son-in-law, Joseph Prior, as well as by many friends and other relatives.She married the love of her life, Philip Dietz, when she was 17 years old. The two of them embarked on the great adventure of life, traveling and enjoying each others company for many years. Along the way, they barely paused the fun to raise four children in Jamaica Estates, Long Island, New York.
Doris and her husband bought a home in Delray Dunes Golf and Country Club in Boynton Beach, Florida and enjoyed several years together there. Sadly, Doris lost her love when he was only 58. She never remarried because, in her words, "I never met another man with dancing eyes!".
Doris remained in Florida for over 50 years.
She was an avid golf player who played into her 90's, and a champion duplicate bridge player.
She loved playing pool, mahjong and dominoes, and was a competitive shopper. Her real passion was travel! She visited every state in the nation, and every continent on the planet - hence her nickname "Dashing Doris"!
Doris spent the last two and a half years in the independent living community at ACTS Bayleigh Chase in Easton, Maryland. She made many good friends while there. Plus, her local family enjoyed the benefit of her company during that time.
Most of all, Doris loved her family. She was always involved with their lives. Several grandchildren lived with her in Florida while in school or transition. Any gathering of 2 or more family members meant Doris was there. A visit from a child, grandchild, or great grandchild would light up her day. Her last plane ride was in December 2022 to celebrate Christmas at her granddaughter Danielle's house in Nashville, because she knew there would be a gathering of family members there.
Doris leaves behind her two sons, Philip (Eva Smorzaniuk), and Peter (Annie Dietz), her daughter, Victoria (Phil Cestaro), nine grandchildren, nine great grandchildren, many nieces and nephews, and lots of four legged children!
As per Doris' request there will be no formal funeral services. Those wishing to make a memorial gift may donate to St. Judes Children's Hospital (www.stjudes.org) or Talbot Humane (www.talbothumane.org). All are welcome to lift a glass and celebrate her wonderful life.
The most frequent question posed to Doris was always "What's your secret to such a long life?" The answer was always "Two Scotches before dinner every night". We love you mom! 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Richard N. Roe

 ST. MICHAELS - Passed away at Talbot Hospice, Easton on December 16, 2023. He was 70.He was the son of the late Norman M. & Virginia "Lee-Lee" Roe. Ricky attended Saints Peter & Paul Catholic School and St.
Michaels High School, graduating in 1971.
After graduating, he began a lifelong career of working on the water in various capacities.
As a commercial waterman, he spent many years catching clams, crabs and oysters. He built his first boat with his father in 1974 and built his second boat in 1985. After numerous requests for custom built boats, he left the water in 1998 to pursue boat building full time. Ricky was highly sought after for both the design and quality of his vessels.
Ricky married his high school sweetheart, the former Kimberly Cummings on August 2, 1974. After retiring, he and Kim spent their winters in Florida, until he could no longer travel due to health reasons. Ricky loved spending time with his family and enjoyed anything to do it the water.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by a brother, Norman. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Kim; a daughter, Misty (Patrick); one son, Rick (Jaren); two granddaughters, Katie (Jason) and Lilly; brotherin-law, Mark Cummings (Kathy) and their family.
Family will receive friends on Thursday, December 21, 2023 from 6:00 PM - 8:00 PM at the Framptom Funeral Home - Ostrowski Chapel of St. Michaels.
Please make donations to: Talbot Hospice Foundation, Inc. 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton.

title: Doris M. Dietz (Murcott)"Dashing Doris"
content:
Doris M. Dietz (Murcott)"Dashing Doris"

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Doris Murcott Dietz died in Easton, Maryland, on December 15, 2023 at the age of 104. She was predeceased by her parents, Edith and Harry Murcott, her beloved husband, Philip Dietz, her brother, Harry Murcott, her sister, Patricia Jensen, her daughter, Andrea Prior, her granddaughter, Michelle Wagner, her daughter-in-law, Penny Dietz, her son-in-law, Joseph Prior, as well as by many friends and other relatives.She married the love of her life, Philip Dietz, when she was 17 years old. The two of them embarked on the great adventure of life, traveling and enjoying each others company for many years. Along the way, they barely paused the fun to raise four children in Jamaica Estates, Long Island, New York.
Doris and her husband bought a home in Delray Dunes Golf and Country Club in Boynton Beach, Florida and enjoyed several years together there. Sadly, Doris lost her love when he was only 58. She never remarried because, in her words, "I never met another man with dancing eyes!".
Doris remained in Florida for over 50 years.
She was an avid golf player who played into her 90's, and a champion duplicate bridge player.
She loved playing pool, mahjong and dominoes, and was a competitive shopper. Her real passion was travel! She visited every state in the nation, and every continent on the planet - hence her nickname "Dashing Doris"!
Doris spent the last two and a half years in the independent living community at ACTS Bayleigh Chase in Easton, Maryland. She made many good friends while there. Plus, her local family enjoyed the benefit of her company during that time.
Most of all, Doris loved her family. She was always involved with their lives. Several grandchildren lived with her in Florida while in school or transition. Any gathering of 2 or more family members meant Doris was there. A visit from a child, grandchild, or great grandchild would light up her day. Her last plane ride was in December 2022 to celebrate Christmas at her granddaughter Danielle's house in Nashville, because she knew there would be a gathering of family members there.
Doris leaves behind her two sons, Philip (Eva Smorzaniuk), and Peter (Annie Dietz), her daughter, Victoria (Phil Cestaro), nine grandchildren, nine great grandchildren, many nieces and nephews, and lots of four legged children!
As per Doris' request there will be no formal funeral services. Those wishing to make a memorial gift may donate to St. Judes Children's Hospital (www.stjudes.org) or Talbot Humane (www.talbothumane.org). All are welcome to lift a glass and celebrate her wonderful life.
The most frequent question posed to Doris was always "What's your secret to such a long life?" The answer was always "Two Scotches before dinner every night". We love you mom! 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Jack Thomas Taylor
content:
Jack Thomas Taylor

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Jack Thomas Taylor of Easton, Maryland passed away on December 24, 2023. Born on September 22, 1936 in Salisbury, Maryland, Jack was the son of Ralph and Grace Taylor.Jack was raised in Cokesbury, Maryland, a very close knit community with a two room schoolhouse, Methodist church and his family's general store.
After graduating from Washington High School in Princess Anne in 1955, Jack enlisted in the Navy. He served four years with the last two stationed at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
In 1956 he married the love of his life, Shirley Simpkins. Jack would fondly tell the story of moving from the small schoolhouse in the 6th grade to the "big city" school in Princess Anne. This is when he first met Shirley and proclaimed that she was the girl he was going to marry. According to Jack she wanted nothing to do with the "country boy" until he won her over their junior year.
After the Navy Jack took a job as a District Game Warden with the Maryland Game and Inland Fish Commission and was posted in Somerset County. Jack and Shirley made their home in Mt Vernon until 1976 when they moved to Easton. Jack had several well-earned promotions within the now Natural Resources Police and retired in July 1992 as Superintendent.
In his retirement Jack enjoyed golf, working in his wood shop, traveling with Shirley and spending time in their cabin in the Shenandoah Valley, Virginia. Jack was a member of Manokin Lodge # 106 AF/AM, life member and past president of Maryland Chiefs of Police 1986-1987 and served on many committees at both the local and state level with regards to law enforcement and conservation.
Jack is survived by his three children Ralph Douglas and wife Michele, Tracy Lednum and husband Mark and Leslie Steen and husband Troy. Also six grandchildren and their families whom he loved dearly. Alexa Taylor (Justin), Stephen Lednum (Kaitlin), Amie Sharp (Wade), Callie Taylor (Jesse), Ashby Steen and Brodie Steen and his eight great grandchildren Hunter, Paisley, Lily, Beau, Hudson, Jack, Cora and Mason.
Jack considered himself truly blessed when Shirley's family became his. Shirley's sisters Nancy Stade and Kathy Beauchamp were like his own. He is predeceased by JD Simpkins, Shirley's brother.
Following Shirley's death in 2012 he met and married Frances Elliott in 2015. She provided a welcome companionship these last eight years.
A visitation will be held at Framptom Funeral Home-Ostrowski Chapel 312 S. Talbot Street in St. Michaels on Saturday December 30,2023 from 10:00 to 12:00, followed by burial at Asbury Methodist Church in Mt Vernon at 3:00. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Talbot Hospice Foundation 586 Cynwood Dr Easton MD 21601 or the Asbury Methodist Church 13263 Renshaw Rd Princess Anne MD 21853.
Arrangements are entrusted to the Framptom Funeral Home-Ostrowski Chapel, St. Michaels, and the Hinman Funeral Home of Princess Anne, MD.

 accomplishments as her 7 children, 6 grandchildren, 2 great-grandchildren, and 59-year devoted marriage. She died December 15, 2023 at age 93. Margaret was born in Pierre, South Dakota in 1930, one of four siblings growing up in the Great Depression. She graduated from Pierre High School, Cottey College, University of Minnesota, and Johns Hopkins School of Nursing.She worked in the Johns Hopkins neonatal unit and met Robert Trever during his medical residency. The couple married in 1954 and moved to Easton, Maryland in 1958. Her husband's solo medical practice, which served generations of patients on the Delmarva, would have been impossible without her.
Throughout her life, Margaret prioritized giving back to the community. Her numerous causes included the Neighborhood Center, Talbot Library, YMCA, and United Way.
Her volunteer roles included tutor, lifeguard, and swim instructor. An outspoken believer in education, she was honored to serve a term on the Talbot County School Board and was a life-long learner herself. She was also an active member of St. Mark's Methodist congregation in Easton and enjoyed multi-faith worship services.
After her husband was diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease in his late 70s, she supported his ability to stay in the family home and exercise on the Easton Rails-to-Trails with their dog Jak until Robert's death in 2013.
Her 7 children, 6 grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren survive her. We are thankful for the support and care she received in her final years from family members, friends, medical, hospice, and other care staff.
In lieu of flowers, please donate to a charity of your choice, or perform an act of kindness or community service in Margaret's honor.

 WITTMAN, MD - Bonnie Faye Roe passed away peacefully at home surrounded by her family, on December 18, 2023. She was 65 years old.Bonnie was born on October 28, 1958, in Easton Maryland to Robert Lee Roe Sr and Elsie Louise Dyer. She is proceeded in death by her daughter Annie Faye Schmitt, and brothers Robert Lee Roe Jr and Mike Gallagher.

title: Gail Yourison
content:
Gail Yourison

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 361
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Gail Richardson Yourison, 84, of Easton, Maryland passed away on December 11, 2023, after a lengthy illness from Vascular Dementia.Gail was born in Berlin, Maryland on August 17th, 1939. The daughter of E. Peter Richardson and Virginia Quillin Richardson. Gail graduated from Stephen Decatur High School where she was very active in varsity sports. While at Stephen Decatur she met and later married her husband of 39 years, Ralph G. Yourison, predeceased.
Gail retired from the State of Marland Income Tax Division and worked as a Branch Manager of Annapolis Banking and Trust early in her career. A true Marylander, Gail enjoyed spending time with her family during visits and vacations to Ocean City, Maryland, as well as rooting for her favorite Maryland sports teams and especially watching Maryland Basketball. As an Eastern Shore girl at heart, Gail loved cooking and her favorite dish was Chicken and Dumplings which was a recipe handed down for generations. She also loved Maryland Crab Cakes and especially Stuffed Shrimp.
After residing, working, and raising her family in the Annapolis area, Cape St. Claire for over twenty years, Gail relocated to Salisbury, MD to be closer to her parents, where her and her husband lived, worked and retired. Gail then moved to Easton, Maryland where she enjoyed being close and spending time with her children and grandchildren who lived in the area. Encouraged to go see the world and travel, Gail took several trips including cruises to Bermuda and Europe as well as travelling to Italy with family to tour Rome and participate in an Olive Harvest while in Umbria.
Gail enjoyed her weekly aerobics class with friends at the YMCA and created beautiful silk flower arrangements as a hobby. For adventure, Gail discovered the world of motor biking and rode back saddle touring the state of Maryland on her friends Harley Davidson.
Gail is survived by her older sister, Patricia Lewis of Delaware; her daughter Teresa Pierce, Easton, MD; son, Michael Yourison, Sarasota, FL.; five grandchildren, and fifteen great-grandchildren in Maryland, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey.
In lieu of Flowers, please donate to your local Hospice. A celebration of life is planned with family in the Spring.

title: Ellie W. Taylor
content:
Ellie W. Taylor

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 638
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NEWBURYPORT, MA - Ellie Taylor died peacefully December 19, 2023, after a long battle with dementia. Ellie was born Eleanor Merryman Ward on April 6, 1940, to Nathaniel and Eleanor Ward of Baltimore, MD, but she grew up in Greensboro, NC and was very much "Ellie" from her earliest years. She spent summers as a young girl in Blowing Rock, NC, learning to ride and love horses. She attended The Madeira School in McLean, VA, where she formed friendships that were a source of support, joy and love throughout her life, and studied at Duke University before marrying and starting a family. Ellie was an incredibly strong woman who always put others first. She was a wonderful and devoted mother of three, and a trusted friend who could always be counted on to remember every birthday and anniversary and to know how to acknowledge whatever the occasion in the most thoughtful and perfectly appropriate manner.She spent many years caring for loved ones in need, first as primary caregiver to her daughter Gina throughout her 8-year battle with cancer, and then as caregiver to her former husband John Taylor, who was diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's disease.
When she wasn't caring for others - and even while she was - Ellie was often busy volunteering or working.
As a young mother in Charlotte, NC, in the 1970s she was an advocate for women's rights and worked with grassroots organizations to help revitalize Uptown Charlotte. After moving to Oxford, MD, she worked in the family boatyard and as a buyer for a local fine clothing store. She later relocated to Washington, DC, where she studied Russian history and art to become a docent at the Hillwood Museum.
Finally, after returning to Maryland's Eastern Shore, she became a certified personal trainer and developed a loyal (and fit!) following among her clients at Body Watts Fitness Studio in Easton, MD. She very much enjoyed living on the tributaries that feed the Chesapeake Bay, but undeniably preferred her dogs to boats. In caring for her former husband and then with her own diagnosis, Ellie fought a courageous and stoic battle against the pain and loss that goes along with dementia. She eventually found peace and was extremely grateful for her dear friends and members of her community even as her memories faded and reorganized themselves. She was a welcome force of positive energy and brought joy to her fellow residents and the wonderful staff at Avita of Newburyport, where she spent her final years enveloped in love. Throughout it all, Ellie drew strength and purpose from the words of Ms. Madeira, founder of The Madeira School: "Function in disaster, finish in style." Indeed, she did both, and in so doing made the world a better place. She was kind and generous, and was loved by all who were fortunate enough to know her. Ellie is survived by two of her three children from her first marriage to Philip Conner: daughter Lisa and son-in-law David Sweet of Rye, NH, and son Philip (Jr) and daughter-in-law Laura Conner of West Hartford, CT. She was preceded in death by her eldest daughter Gina in 1988. Her legacy is also alive and well in her four grandchildren, Ella, Sam and Nate Sweet and Zach Conner. While her journey was difficult, her family would like to thank the many friends, caregivers and more than a couple strangers who provided support, comfort and guidance along the way, helping Ellie to navigate her decline with dignity and a high quality of life. A celebration of her life will be held for family and friends in the spring.
Memorial donations can be made to Shining Hope Farms (https://shininghopefarms.org/).
To view Ellie's Online Tribute, send condolences to the family, or for more information, visit www.csnh.com.
Assisting the family with arrangements is the Cremation Society of NH, Manchester.

title: Jean M. Jordan
content:
Jean M. Jordan

 December 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 YORK, PA - Jean Marie Jordan passed peacefully on December 26, 2023. Jean, daughter of the late Celestine and Joseph Jordan, was born in Bloomsburg, PA on October 16, 1961, or maybe October 17th.Mom swears it was the 16th. Jean found some hospital documents that said the 17th. So, let's just say she was born around midnight. Jean moved with her family to Denton, MD when she was one.
As a child, Jean believed if you opened a tube of Pillsbury rolls, the Doughboy would pop out.
She opened many tubes and Mom got her an official Doughboy toy. The first in her massive collection of Doughboys. Jean was a fan of Barry Manilow. One of her happiest days was when she won his new album by being the correct caller to the radio station. Jean was active in 4-H as a child.
Jean graduated from North Caroline High School in 1979. She won the Home Economics Award for her sewing skills. She went to Hagerstown Business School to learn clerical skills. She worked as a secretary for the health department in Denton and Preston Trucking.
Jean served on the board of Caroline County Hospice. Later, Jean earned a B.S. in elementary education from Villa Maria College in Erie, PA (1993) and a M.S. in special education from Bloomsburg University (1995). Jean began teaching in 1995 in Dorchester County Public Schools. She taught at Mace's Lane School in Cambridge. Jean taught in Carroll County Publics Schools (Oklahoma Road Middle School and Robert Moton Elementary School) until her retirement in 2021. Jean was a dedicated educator who served students with special needs.
She ensured her students received the best education and made them feel valued. Jean was an active member of the Carroll County Education Association, serving as a building representative for years and participating in the March for Education in 2019, in Annapolis.
Jean loved sewing, crafting, and traveling, especially with her sisters. There were times she wasn't sure she was going to make it back home, but we always kept her safe. She loved going on boat rides with her brothers (when the boats worked!). She enjoyed growing up on the Eastern Shore, loved a good, fried hard crab, and spending the day on the beach. Jean was a die-hard Orioles fan, never losing faith in them.
She made the trip to Cooperstown when Cal was inducted.
Jean was preceded in death by her parents, her brother Joe Jordan, her beloved boxer, Fife, and members of the Brown, Ryan, and Jordan families.
Jean is survived by her siblings: Susan and Tom Bianca, John Jordan, Terri Jordan, Jeff and Lynn Jordan, Celeste Jordan, and Val Jordan (Joe's wife). She was very proud of her nieces and nephews: Ryan Jordan, Josh Jordan, Jennifer Jordan, Alex Bianca, Ann Bianca, Jackie Jordan, Alyssa Jordan, and Anthony Bianca.
A viewing will be held New Year's Day, Monday, January 1, 2024, from 6 to 8 PM at Moore Funeral Home, P.A. 12 S. 2nd St. Denton, MD.
The Mass of Christian Burial will be at her childhood church, St. Elizabeth's in Denton, MD on January 2, 2024, at 11 AM. Burial will follow at Old St. Joseph's Cemetery in Cordova, MD.
The family requests donations be made in Jean's memory to St. Jude's Children's Hospital 501 St. Jude Place Memphis, TN 38105 or stjude.org, Lifetime Well International 24321 Shore Hwy. Denton, MD 21629 or lifetimewellsinternational.org, or you could be like Jean and become an organ donor.
Now, it is up to Mom to take care of Jeannie and take her home. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 DELAWARE - Robert Burns Staats of Dover passed away Monday, December 18, 2023, at the Delaware Hospice Center, Milford. He was 91.Mr. Staats was born June 25, 1932, in Dover, Delaware to the late Alvin Burns Staats and Elizabeth A. Yetter Staats. He graduated from Dover High School in 1950 and was covaledictorian.
After high school he went to the University of Utica, Utica, NY. graduating with a AA in Business Studies. Then he went to the University of Texas/Austin graduating with a BA degree in Business Economics.
He served in the United States Army during the Korean War, upon his discharge he worked as a salesman for 32 years at Sears and Robuck Company, where he retired. After Sears he worked at Walmart as a greeter for 8 years. He enjoyed playing chess and board games as well as reading, gardening, and traveling.
He loved to go to McDonald's for coffee with his nephew Randy.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his son, Michael Allen Staats and brothers, Ronald D. and William R. Staats.
He is survived by his partner and best friend, Roy Coursey of Denton, MD; sister, Karen E. Carter (Dwight) of Dover; sistersin-law, Edna Staats of Dover and Janie Staats of Collinsville, Ill; daughter-in-law, Deborah Staats of Dover; grandchildren Erica and Mindy Dunlap; great-grandchildren, Aidan Dunlap, Zachary, Maddix and Cole Snyder; nieces, Debbie Whitmore of DE, Kimberly Murray and her husband John of DE, Denise Tracy and her wife Pauline of DE and Julie Frost of Ill; nephews, William R. Staats, Jr. of DE, Ronald Staats, Jr. of Ill, Kevin Tracy and his wife Angie of SC, Owen Tracy of NC and Myron Tracy and his wife Melissa of FL.
To the staff of Dr. Shuck and Dr Aye Thank you for the care you gave Robert. Delaware Hospice Center we couldn't have done it without you. Heartfelt "Thank You!" to the staff.

title: Mary "Margaret" Russum
content:
Mary "Margaret" Russum

 December 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries

 Words

 CENTREVILLE - Mary Margaret "Margaret" Russum of Queenstown and Centreville, MD passed away on December 25th, 2023 at home, surrounded by family.She was 89.
Born on September 29, 1934, in Church Hill, MD she was the daughter of the late James Webster Kimble and Georgianna Minch Kimble.
She was one of 10 children. She grew up in the Church Hill area and attended school in Church Hill and Centreville. She was a graduate of Centreville High School, Class of 1953.
On January 2, 1954, she married the late Charles Edwin Russum. They were married for 62 years before his death in 2016. They resided in Chestertown and then on several farms in the Church Hill and Centreville area, before settling in the Queenstown area where they lived for over 50 years.
Margaret was a homemaker and a Foster Parent to 41 children over 26 years. She and Ed also worked for many years cleaning the branch offices for Queenstown Bank.
Margaret enjoyed gardening, crocheting, playing Bingo, but most of all she enjoyed the time she spent with her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was an active parishioner for many years with Our Mother of Sorrows and St. Peter's Parish. She was a member and past president of the Altar and Rosary Society, past president and member of the parish Activities Committee, working many church dinners and Lawn Fetes.
She is survived by her four children: James A. Russum of Annapolis, MD, Teresa Hammer (Alan), of Centreville, MD, Shirley Anthony (Lonnie), of Queenstown, MD and Charles Franklin Russum (Terri) of Centreville, MD.; two brothers, David Kimble of Vallejo, CA, Joseph Kimble of Church Hill, MD; one sister, Barbara Anderson of Cordova, MD; 8 Grandchildren and 12 Great Grandchildren.
In addition to her husband and parents, she was predeceased by her great-grandson Shawn Hammer; brothers Eugene Kimble, Richard Kimble, Bernard Kimble, Franklin Kimble and James Kimble and one sister, Rita Hall.
A visitation will be held on Wednesday January 3rd, 2023 from 6-8 p.m. at Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home, P.A., 408 South Liberty Street, Centreville, MD 21617. title: K. Diane Baumgartner
content:
K. Diane Baumgartner

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 910
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - K. Diane Baumgartner, a beacon of light whose vibrant spirit danced through the currents of life, passed away surrounded by the love of her husband and children on November 9, 2023. Born on September 30, 1949, to John Walter Baumgartner and Anna Elizabeth Bell, Diane grew up on a family farm before moving to Vienna, MD where she embraced every aspect of life with an adventurous and joyful heart, spending many of her days at her grandmothers' home playing the piano.Diane's passion for movement brought her and Edward Farley together through the rhythmic steps of contra dancing in 2004. Their souls intertwined, leading to a seaside wedding in Florida on February 29, 2008. As partners in life, they sailed through the ebbs and flows, dancing along many shores and anchored their lives not far from the water's edge in St. Michaels, MD.
Diane, a devoted mother, shared her boundless love with her children Michael Hawkins, Ashley Dejter, Alex Hawkins, and Nick Hawkins, whose lives she shaped alongside Chester Hawkins. Her nurturing heart extended to her eldest grandson Maison Hawkins, whom she raised for 12 years. Affectionately known as 'Mom-mom,' she enveloped her grandchildren Ethan Hawkins, Cru Dejter, Eleanora Hawkins, Wade Dejter, Nolan Hawkins, Axel Hawkins, Beau Hawkins, and Ezra Hawkins in the warmth of her love, as vast and embracing as the ocean itself.
Diane's siblings - Nancy Reid, John Baumgartner, Don 'Bumpy' Baumgartner, and Betty Anne 'Bee' Harding- were her close friends in life's journey. Together with Bee, they raised their children side by side, their laughter echoing through countless ocean vacations.
Her essence was one of acceptance and empathy, a sanctuary for others, offering a peace that calmed the worries of many. Her children recall a home where anger was a stranger, and life's lessons were learned through living rather than lecturing. Diane's intuitive nature and presence made you feel like the center of her universe, a feeling cherished by all who knew her.
Diane's diverse professional endeavors, spanning three distinct careers, were a unified expression of her deep exploration into various cultural practices of healing the human body.
Her first act was as a dancer, gracing stages with performances that captured the hearts of audiences and the praise of critics. A graduate of the University of Maryland, she earned her Bachelor of Arts in Dance in 1971, and subsequently, her Master of Arts from the University of Illinois in 1973. Diane's fervor for dance propelled her into the roles of instructor and choreographer at renowned institutions, including her tenure as a dance instructor at Sweet Briar College from 1976 to 1978, an artist in residence at Towson State in 1979, and an assistant professor of dance at Goucher College from 1979 to 1982.
Her dedication to the arts continued as she choreographed and taught modern and jazz at the Baltimore School for the Arts, the University of Maryland, and the Peabody Conservatory from 1982 to 1984, leaving an indelible mark on the dance community.
When motherhood called, Diane embraced it fully, only to reemerge in her second act as a nurturing nurse. After obtaining her Bachelor of Arts in Nursing from Stevenson University and her Master's from Wesley College, Diane's impact as a nurse was profound and far-reaching.
Known endearingly as 'Mrs. B' by the hundreds of students she mentored, Diane's legacy at Anne Arundel Community College and Chesapeake College is measured not just in the over 500 nursing students she educated, but in the countless lives they went on to touch. Her tenure there, which spanned a significant part of her career, was marked by the heartfelt support and unwavering belief she instilled in her students. Beyond her teaching, Diane brought an innovative spirit to Anne Arundel Hospital, where she introduced and developed a Reiki program, weaving her knowledge of holistic practices into the fabric of patient care, thereby enhancing the healing process with the energy and empathy that were the hallmarks of her life's work.
Diane's zest for life found its zenith in her sixties as she embraced the role of a certified yoga instructor which was not just a pursuit of personal well-being, but an extension of her lifelong commitment to nurturing others. With her characteristic enthusiasm, Diane traversed the world, seeking further certifications and deepening her practice amidst the serenity of these paradises. At the Talbot County Senior Center, she offered her expertise often without charge, making the transformative power of yoga accessible to her community. Her teaching extended to the sandy shores of OBX and Myrtle Beach, where family vacations were graced with her leading yoga sessions against the backdrop of the ocean-a place she felt most at peace.
These sessions were more than mere exercises; they were the confluence of Diane's love for the water, her passion for teaching, and her innate ability to bring calm and balance into the lives of those around her, leaving a legacy for her family and community.
Diane's life was a celebration, a dance of joy, love, and compassion. As we bid her farewell, we invite you to share in a celebration of her life, honoring a soul that moved gracefully through this world, leaving behind a legacy of love and cherished memories.
Celebration of Life Service: January 7, 2024 3 PM at Living Waters Assembly in Denton, Md In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Living Waters Assembly, 9058 Double Hills Rd, Denton, MD 21629 "May the waves carry you home, and the dance never end."
For online condolences, visit www.fhnfuneralhome.com

title: Martin Snow
content:
Martin Snow

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 HENDERSON - Martin Andrew Snow, 75, passed away at his home on December 2, 2023. He was born in Baltimore, Maryland to Charles and Margaret Snow.Martin was taught by the Catholic Nuns of The Shrine of The Little Flower.
Martin's father bought farmland in Henderson, Maryland and the family would spend weekends there building a home. They moved permanently to Henderson, in 1962. Martin graduated from North Caroline High School in 1966. He proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1968-1972. After serving in the military, he worked on his family's farm, primarily planting, and harvesting corn and soybeans.
Martin developed a passion for planting gardens with a variety of fruit and vegetables, and he became a member of a gardening club.
He worked for Mears Point Marina for several years, then continued to work on the farm. He loved to fish, hunt, and go crabbing with his many friends and brother Philip. Martin was well-loved, and he will be missed by all.
He is survived by his brother Dr. Philip Snow, nephew James Lindlof, niece Kristen Cardozo, 3 great-nephews, 2 great nieces.
He is preceded in death by his sister Joan Lindlof and his parents Charles and Margaret Snow.
The family plans to hold an intimate Memorial for Martin in the early New Year. Please contact the family if you wish to join us.

 CAMBRIDGE - Mary Beth Adams, 77, of Cambridge passed away on Saturday, December 30, 2023 at TidalHealth Peninsula Regional with her daughter holding her hand. title: Former first lady Melania Trump's mother has died
author: Staff Writer
content:
Former first lady Melania Trump's mother has died

 January 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Amalija Knavs, the mother of former first lady Melania Trump, has died.Trump announced the death late Tuesday without disclosing the cause.
"It is with deep sadness that I announce the passing of my beloved mother, Amalija," Trump wrote on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. "Amalija Knavs was a strong woman who always carried herself with grace, warmth, and dignity. She was entirely devoted to her husband, daughters, grandson, and son-in-law. We will miss her beyond measure and continue to honor and love her legacy."
Donald Trump said at a New Year's Eve celebration at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida, that his mother-in-law was "very ill" and his wife was with her at a hospital in Miami.
"It's a tough one, very tough one," he said of the situation.
During the Trump presidency, the first lady's mother lived in New York along with her father, Viktor Knavs, and occasionally appeared at the White House. Amalija Knavs was at a 2018 ceremony where the first lady debuted her "Be Best" public awareness campaign to help children.
"This is a very sad night for the entire Trump family!!!" Trump wrote on his social media site, Truth Social. "Melania's great and beautiful mother, Amalija, has just gone to a beautiful place in the sky. She was an incredible woman, and will be missed far beyond words!"
Melania Trump sponsored her parents' immigration to the United States, and they took the oath to become citizens at a New York City courthouse in 2018, while Trump was president. The Slovenian immigrants, a former car dealer and a textile factory worker, had been living in the U.S. as permanent residents.

title: Baltimore native and celebrity makeup artist dies
author: Staff Writer
content:
Baltimore native and celebrity makeup artist dies

 January 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — Reggie Wells, who spent more than 30 years as Oprah Winfrey's personal makeup artist and worked with former first lady Michelle Obama, Beyoncé, Halle Berry and numerous other celebrities, has died. He was 76.The Emmy winner and Baltimore County native died there Monday of natural causes, his niece Kristina Conner told The Associated Press on Thursday.
"He was always so full of life," Conner said. "Very energetic. He loved to make you laugh. And he always saw the best in people. He saw so much potential in so many people."
Wells had returned to Baltimore later in life to be closer to his aging father, The Baltimore Banner reported. In addition to his glamorous life as a celebrity makeup artist, Wells spent time making over women in a retirement community in the Park Heights neighborhood and had them professionally photographed.
Wells received five Daytime Emmy nominations for his work on "The Oprah Winfrey Show," winning a statuette in 1995. He frequently traveled the globe with Winfrey, including trips to South Africa, where she opened a school.
Wells was one of seven children born to John Henry Wells, a bus driver, and Ada Wells, a nurse. He graduated from Baltimore City College and the Maryland Institute College of Art, according to the Banner. He moved to New York City in the mid-1970s to pursue work as a makeup artist.
He worked with a range of magazines, including Glamour and Harper's Bazaar. At Essence, he did makeup for models and celebrities who graced the magazine's covers. That's how he connected with Winfrey and other celebrities.
He also worked with Whitney Houston, Diahann Carroll, Aretha Franklin and Joan Rivers. He went to work for Winfrey full time in Chicago in 1990.
Wells also created his own line of makeup for Black women in the early days when few products for their skin tones were available. In 2000, he published a book, "Face Painting: African American Beauty Techniques from an Emmy-Winning Makeup Artist." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fashion icon known for her eye-catching style dies at 102
author: ASSOCIAED PRESS
content:
Fashion icon known for her eye-catching style dies at 102

 March 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ASSOCIAED PRESS | Section: News 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NEW YORK — Iris Apfel, a textile expert, interior designer and fashion celebrity known for her eccentric style, has died. She was 102.Her death was confirmed by her commercial agent, Lori Sale, who called Apfel "extraordinary." No cause of death was given. It was also announced on her verified Instagram page on Friday, which a day earlier had celebrated that Leap Day represented her 102nd-and-a-half birthday.
Born Aug. 29, 1921, Apfel was famous for her irreverent, eye-catching outfits, mixing haute couture and oversized costume jewelry. A classic Apfel look would, for instance, pair a feather boa with strands of chunky beads, bangles and a jacket decorated with Native American beadwork.
With her big, round, black-rimmed glasses, bright red lipstick and short white hair, she stood out at every fashion show she attended.
Her style was the subject of museum exhibits and a documentary film, "Iris," directed by Albert Maysles.
"I'm not pretty, and I'll never be pretty, but it doesn't matter," she once said. "I have something much better. I have style."
Apfel enjoyed late-in-life fame on social media, amassing nearly 3 million followers on Instagram, where her profile declares: "More is more & Less is a Bore." On TikTok, she drew 215,000 followers as she waxed wise on things fashion and style and promoted recent collaborations.
"Being stylish and being fashionable are two entirely different things," she said in one TikTok video. "You can easily buy your way into being fashionable. Style, I think is in your DNA. It implies originality and courage."
She never retired, telling "Today": "I think retiring at any age is a fate worse than death. Just because a number comes up doesn't mean you have to stop." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Farming and fair communities remember the late F. Grove Miller
author: Carl Hamilton & Jane Bellmyer cahamilton@cecilwhig.com
content:
Farming and fair communities remember the late F. Grove Miller

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton & Jane Bellmyer cahamilton@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 1500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The name F. Grove Miller Jr. is synonymous with the Cecil County Fair or, from a more conservative standpoint, it is at least forever intertwined with that annual Fair Hill summer event that spans nine days and attracts more than 75,000 people.Undeniably, the Cecil County Fair is high on the long list of achievements and community contributions of Miller, who died on Monday at Christiana Care's Union Hospital in Elkton after a brief illness. Miller was 96.
"He is one of the reasons we have the Cecil County Fair," said Wayne Stafford, whose 120-acre beef and crops home farm in Calvert is about one mile away from the 350-acre dairy farm to which Miller, his ancestors and predecessors have been connected to as owners and workers for seven generations.
Don Moore, 60, has lived and worked on his family's three-generation farm, which is next to the Miller's farm, all of his life, and he, too, credited Miller for playing a major role in creating and developing the annual Cecil County Fair.
"He was among a handful of local farmers who saw a need to have this kind of community event," commented Moore, who described Miller as "easygoing" and a "wonderful neighbor."
Miller was approximately 25 years old in 1953, when he and four other farmers representing the Calvert, Cecilton and Colora Granges met to discuss the possibility of holding an annual Cecil County Fair. (The other four farmers, all of whom have since passed away, are Robert Carrion, Bill Groff, Walt Mason and and Ray Mueller, who was Cecil County's Agricultural Extension Agent at the time.)
Miller and his four fellow farmers founded the Cecil County Fair Board and that group, looking for a suitable place to hold the annual event, approached the late William DuPont, who owned the 5,400-acre parcel known today as Fair Hill Natural Resources Management Area.
DuPont welcomed and supported the idea, so much so that he shared the expense of the fledgling Cecil County Fair throughout its first years and even donated a grandstand and several outbuildings for displays and livestock.
The first Cecil County Fair was held on a portion of that Fair Hill property on July 31,1954. It was a one-day event, running from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., and admission was free. Approximately 750 people attended that inaugural Cecil County Fair.
Today, more than 75,000 people attend the annual Cecil County Fair, which lasts nine days, and there are over 7,000 entries from about 1,200 open and 4-H exhibitors.
Miller served on the Cecil County Fair Board for 24 years, stepping down in 1978, when he was replaced by one his two sons, Al Miller, who was about 24 then. Working in similar fashion on an even grander scale, Miller left to join the Maryland State Fair Board, on which he served the next 40 years as chairman. At age 90, Miller stepped down from the Maryland State Fair Board in December 2017. In full-circle fashion, Robbie Miller, who is Miller's 36-year-old grandson, now serves on the Maryland State Fair Board.
Miller once wrote an essay of sorts regarding his philosophy when it comes to community fairs. Considering that the Cecil County Fair is a great part of his legacy, these words written by him are profound:
"First and foremost, fairs are about families, young and old coming together to participate in or enjoy watching competitions and exhibitions. When I see grandparents taking their grandchildren around the Fair, I say, 'Now, that's what the Fair is all about'…older generations passing on what they have learned to future generations and younger generations proudly sharing their new skills with the older generation."
'A PASSION FOR AGRICULTURE'
Miller's resume reflects how he volunteered a wealth of his time for decades to numerous other boards and groups, including the University of Maryland Board of Regents, the Maryland 4-H Board, the Maryland Land Preservation Board, the Fair Hill Races Board, on which he served as chairman; the Fair Hill DNR Long Range Plan, also as chairman; the Maryland Farm Bureau, on which he served four years as president; the Cecil County Department of Social Services Board and the Union Hospital Board. He also served on the board for County Bank and Trust/PNC Bank and the Bainbridge Museum Board.
Al Miller, who lives in Calvert, recalled with a chuckle how a public speaker once commented from the podium, "If Grove Miller was paid a dollar for every hour he volunteered in Cecil County and throughout Maryland, he would be a millionaire."
Most of his endeavors focused on supporting his fellow farmers. Fittingly, Miller, who is described in his obituary as "a well-respected farmer in Cecil County," was inducted into the Maryland Agricultural Hall of Fame.
"He had a passion for agriculture," said Stafford, who carpooled with Miller to and from Randallstown for the monthly Maryland Farm Bureau meetings during the later part of the 1970s, which gave him an opportunity to learn from the seasoned farmer, agriculture advocate and community volunteer.
Son of the late Carl Stafford, another well-known Cecil County farmer, 67-year-old Stafford continued, "He got to be a mentor for me. Grove was a great mentor. He knew how to advocate governmentally. Many times I went to him for advice."
Along those lines, Stafford noted, "Grove is the inspiration I had to pursue an active involvement in the Farm Bureau."
Moore made a similar observation of Miller, commenting, "He was very active in the community and he was an excellent spokesperson for agriculture and the community as well."
FRIENDS IN HIGH PLACES
Miller knew and interacted with many people in leadership roles while serving as a point-person, so to speak, for agriculture, as well as for other areas related to the committees and groups on which he volunteered. One of those people was longtime Cecil County resident David Rudolph, who served in the Maryland General Assembly in Annapolis as a state delegate from 1995 to 2015.
"Grove Miller was one of the finest gentlemen I have ever had the opportunity to know. He was known throughout the State of Maryland as an individual dedicated to making his county and state a better place. In my opinion and I am sure many Marylanders, he personified the term 'Statesman.' This leadership is especially true at the Maryland State Fair, where his vision and commitment will be felt for generations to come," Rudolph said, before remarking, "I will always be honored to have called him my friend and colleague. This is truly a sad day for all Marylanders."
Al Miller, 70, reported that his father also was close to late Maryland State Senators Walter M. Baker, who served from 1979 to 2003, and Thomas V. Mike Miller Jr., who served from 1975 to 2020.
"He was deeply connected with Annapolis," said Al Miller, who has served as a Cecil County Councilman for the past six years.
Along those lines, Miller hosted the late Louis L. Goldstein, who served as Maryland's comptroller from 1959 to 1998, on a tour of the Fair Hill property when it still was owned by the DuPont family, according to Al Miller, who then opined, "My father was very instrumental in the State of Maryland buying that property."
In addition to Al Miller, whose wife is Karen, Miller's other surviving children are his other son, Kenneth S. Miller (Kay) of Milton, Del., and daughter, Dianne E. Russell (Bill) of North East. Miller and his wife, Arlene, had been married 70 years when she died in May 2021.
A GOOD MAN
D. Andrew Cashman, who has served as Maryland State Fair general manager for many years, worked closely with Miller.
"Grove is a man whose name has always been synonymous with fairs and fairness. For more than 50 years, this visionary has provided service to the Cecil County Fair, the Cecil County Breeders Fair, the Maryland State Fair, the MAAFS and the IAFE. He has gained the respect of thousands of people in the fair, 4-H, agriculture and business industries, as well as in the state legislature. He is always willing to share his knowledge, energy and understanding of Maryland fairs, agriculture and politics," Cashman summarized.
Cashman noted that Miller proudly served in the U.S. Navy as a medic during World War II and the Korean Conflict.
"Miller, who grew up on a farm and was a 4-H member, believed in service to his community and his country. His service was demonstrated early in life when he interrupted his college education for military service. Following his military service, he and his brother (the late Jack Miller) decided to go into dairy farming together," he outlined.
It is clear that Cashman respected Miller as a volunteer and as a friend.
"Grove Miller, best known for his great smile, robust laugh, positive attitude and willingness to work hard, has helped to make the Maryland Fair industry the best," Cashman said.
Al Miller often turned to his father for guidance when making decisions, he said. And the sound advice that his father gave him always reflected wisdom gained through his years of experience, Al Miller added.
He described his father this way: "My dad was my best friend, my mentor and my idol." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is primarily an obituary honoring the late F. Grove Miller, detailing his life, death, and legacy. While it heavily references his agricultural contributions, the main purpose is to memorialize him, making 'Obituaries' the best fit.
