But there's one thing, I forgot to say,
I'm so in love with you,
Denise, Denise, my brightest angel,
You're here one day, one beautiful day,
And now you've gone away,
Denise, Denise, my brightest angel,
It's in God's wish that you should go,
We all will miss you so,
Memories and tears fill my life every day,
How can I make my agonizing pain go away?
I heard her voice in my dreams last night,
…and she said to me, "Please don't cry,"
And she whispered "good-bye", she's livin' happily
Denise, Denise, my brightest angel,
You're here one day, one beautiful day,
And now you've gone away,
Denise, Denise, my brightest angel,
It's in God's wish that you should go,
We all will miss you so,
Denise, Denise my Brightest Angel,
You're here on day, one beautiful day,
And now you've gone away,
Denise, Denise my brightest angel,
It's in God's wish that you should go,
We all miss you so,
It's in God's wish that you should go,
I will miss you so." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a memorial poem announcing the death of a 16‑year‑old, which fits the Obituaries category. It is not a public notice about services or legal matters, so Obituaries is the best match.

title: Sailing leader and community trailblazer Diana Mautz dies
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Sailing leader and community trailblazer Diana Mautz dies

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Diana Mautz was a tough, brilliant woman.From leading sailing crews to spending time with her two sons, she was known for her compassion, unshaken moral compass and generous acts of service.
Mautz died after several years of critical health complications on Thursday, March 14, according to her family.
"She's a loving lady. She always gave back, not for recognition or anything; she gave back from her heart," Daniel Mautz, Diana's son, said.
Originally from Galion, Ohio, Diana Mautz spent her life making St. Michaels home for her and her family. She led a life of leadership, mentorship and philanthropy.
Her family and friends described her as an invincible force shaping the St. Michaels Business Association and helping transform the local economy.
Mautz attended Saint Xavier University in Chicago, Illinois, before meeting and then marrying her husband, John Fredrick Mautz.
She moved to St. Michaels shortly after the birth of her first son, Johnny Mautz, in 1970, so she could follow her love for sailing. Four years later, she gave birth to her son Daniel.
Mautz built one of the East Coast's most extensive junior sailing programs. She directed junior sailing programs at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, the Tred Avon Yacht Club, the Miles River Yacht Club and what was then known as the Talbot County YMCA.
Johnny Mautz said his mother's love for sailing and teaching kids to sail was a driving force in her life. He said she instilled a competitive spirit in her students. Many of the kids she taught went on to sail competitively, and some even went on to the Olympics.
Cathy Schmidt, a friend of Mautz's, said they taught sailing side by side for 25 years.
"Deep in our hearts, we all wanted our students to love sailing, and silliness was the perfect catalyst," Schmidt said. "Scavenger hunts, 4th of July boat parades, popsicle stick Olympics, candy mark, instructor paddling races, turtle dancing and field trips all over the river too numerous to mention, unlock our inner child when mentioned between old sailing friends. These precious memories are, in a way, Diana's legacy."
In 1979, unbeknownst to her husband, Diana Mautz purchased Carpenter Street Saloon on C-Street in St. Michaels, which still operates today as one of the remaining iconic Eastern Shore gathering spots.
When Mautz purchased the saloon, it was not a place people considered a shining star, her family said, but she saw potential.
"She went in and found the best in everyone," Johnny Mautz said. "They may have been the roughest crowd around in that bar, but they were the sweetest of men and women … All of them had hearts and souls of gold."
Daniel Mautz said his mom transformed the saloon into a calm place. He said her work in the saloon taught her many lessons and helped her grow as a business owner and leader.
Johnny Mautz recounted how, as a child, witnessing men trying to intimidate her, his mother would just look them right in the eye and not back down.
"She did things that most women didn't do," he said. "She had no concern, and she had no fear about saying, 'I'm gonna do this.' I think a lot of the men at the time were a little taken aback by this 'pushy gal,' but she was never pushy. She was assertive, and she was never afraid."
Daniel Mautz said he learned from his mother not to back down from a challenge and to be persistent with his goals.
Her family said that Mautz found a way to organize, encourage and lead volunteers to meet the community's needs in every place she lived.
In lieu of flowers, her family has established a Diana Mautz Legacy Fund. They ask that checks are made payable to Foundation for Community Development Inc. or any other correspondence to address 23942 N. Porters Creek Lane, St. Michaels 21663. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a death notice and tribute, focusing on the life and legacy of Diana Mautz, which fits the Obituaries category best, though it also mentions her sailing involvement (Sports) and community contributions (Arts & Culture, Business/Economy).

title: Never forget: Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends
author: RICK STEVENS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Never forget: Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK STEVENS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, I attended a family wedding on Maryland's Eastern Shore, staying overnight in the small village of Cambridge.To pass the time between nuptial obligations, I decided to walk around the town. At the corner of Church and High streets, I encountered the Christ Episcopal Church and its accompanying cemetery, which I later learned has served as a burial ground dating to the 1690s. My innate curiosity led me through the iron gates to stroll among the gravestones. I discovered that four former Maryland governors are buried there, along with generations of local parish families.
Time and weather have rendered many markers nearly illegible, but one stone slab, adorned with an American flag, caught my eye.
Levin J. Newcomb Jr. was born April 27, 1918. He died June 19, 1944, in Normandy, France. Capt. Newcomb was just 26 years old. His marker records he was a member of Company A, 115 Infantry, 29th Division. It's reasonable to assume Capt. Newcomb was the company commander. The marker is engraved with the crossed rifles of an infantryman and the blue and gray yin and yang patch of the 29th Infantry Division. It includes the scripture, "Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends."
At the top are the words, "IN MEMORY OF," a phrase that intrigued me. Why were those words necessary?
It turns out Capt. Newcomb's final resting place is actually Plot G, Row 25, Grave 7 in the Normandy American Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, France. He never came home to Dorchester County.
It was common in that era for servicemembers to be interred close to where they died. Many families, seeking closure or hoping to create a physical connection to their loved ones, placed tributes in their local cemeteries. Those markers allowed them to share their experience of loss with others in the community and perhaps cope with what must have been nearly intolerable grief.
This year marks the 80th anniversary of the Normandy invasion. It's the 80th anniversary of a campaign between June and September of 1944 that saw some 29,000 Americans killed in action.
Today, it's impossible to know the positive impact the fallen might have had on their families and communities across our nation had they survived the war. Robbed of life's bounties and promise, we'll never know how soldiers like Capt. Newcomb would have contributed to the greater good of society. I imagine him sitting in a pew in Christ Church with his wife, June, and young son, Richard, enjoying tasty Maryland crab at picnics, quietly being a pillar of the community … rarely talking about his experiences in combat.
But it was not to be. His brave commitment to a calling greater than himself is his legacy.
Capt. Levin J. Newcomb Jr., and others like him, are why we pause and reflect each Memorial Day. Understandably, I'd never heard of Capt. Newcomb before my unplanned wandering through that small, timeworn garden of remembrance. Yet, I'm honored to have learned a little more about him while researching this message. More importantly, I'm reminded of our explicit duty to "never forget" the contributions of our fallen … wherever they may rest in peace.
Retired Maj. Gen. Rick Stevens is senior vice president and director of business development at Dawson & Associates. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a personal remembrance of a fallen WWII soldier, describing his burial and legacy, which aligns most closely with an obituary-style piece despite being a reflective essay.

title: Former Oxford Fire Co. President John Hanes 'never met a stranger'
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Former Oxford Fire Co. President John Hanes 'never met a stranger'

 June 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When former Oxford Fire Company President John Hanes died at the end of May, lots of people reached out to his son, Matthew Hanes, with stories of what John meant to them."I knew he was a great man, but I didn't realize he knew so many people," Matthew said.
Matthew remembers a story that came from one of their former neighbors in Oxford.
"She had to go to the hospital, and dad went and sat with her all night in the hospital because her husband was sick at home," he said.
Matthew called it humbling to hear those stories.
"He did a lot of things around Oxford," Matthew said about his father. "A lot of people knew him and liked him a lot."
John died May 30 at his home in Seaford, Delaware, following complications from a triple bypass surgery in October. He was 70.
John, who was born in Cambridge, spent the majority of his life in Oxford. Matthew said his father lived in Oxford for at least 30 years.
Current Oxford Fire Company President Tim Kearns said that John, who was a lifetime member of the Oxford Fire Company, did a good job of bringing people together.
"He was president for an extended period of time, and he managed to organize number of different personalities and get them all on the same wavelength so that they would work together to support the town," Kearns said. "That's not an easy thing to do because you have those that would love to lead, those that don't want to lead, and how do you get that coming together?"
Kearns will miss John's sense of humor the most.
"He liked to almost be that big brother that would always pick on you and make fun of you," Kearns said. "But always in a good way."
Matthew said his father was always there to help anyone.
"(He) never met a stranger, if that makes sense," Matthew said. "He was always open to meeting new people."
John did a lot with his two sons, Matthew said. When Matthew and his brother were kids, they practically lived at the ice rink, he said. John played hockey in the men's league, and Matthew played in the younger league.
John spent 20 years at Safeway, starting as a stocker and working his way up to being manager of multiple stores. Later in his career, John owned and operated Tricrown Inn for Pets, a kennel in Oxford, before retiring.
"Retired and came to help me at my business," Matthew said, laughing.
In his lifetime, John served on the Talbot County Emergency Services Advisory Board and was treasurer for the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association. Matthew said John helped several fire companies "whenever he could."
It started with the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, which John first got involved with in 1969, according to a Facebook post from the Oxford Fire Company.
"I think he got involved when he was younger in Trappe, and that just stemmed from there, pretty much," Matthew said about his father's involvement with volunteer fire organizations.
John is survived by his wife Polly; his sons John Hanes (Leah) and Matthew Hanes (Brooks); his grandchildren Johanna, Josephine, Olivia and Eli and many nieces and nephews.
There will be a celebration of life for Hanes at the Oxford Volunteer Fire Company on Saturday, June 15, from noon to 2 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of a community figure, provides biographical details, and describes funeral arrangements, which are classic elements of an obituary. While it mentions his fire service involvement (public safety), the primary purpose is to memorialize him.

title: Pioneering sex therapist Westheimer dies at 96
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pioneering sex therapist Westheimer dies at 96

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: National 
 
 1402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NEW YORK — Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the diminutive sex therapist who became a pop icon, media star and best-selling author through her frank talk about once-taboo bedroom topics, has died. She was 96.Westheimer died on Friday at her home in New York City, surrounded by her family, according to publicist and friend Pierre Lehu.
Westheimer never advocated risky sexual behavior. Instead, she encouraged an open dialogue on previously closeted issues that affected her audience of millions. Her one recurring theme was there was nothing to be ashamed of.
"I still hold old-fashioned values and I'm a bit of a square," she told students at Michigan City High School in 2002. "Sex is a private art and a private matter. But still, it is a subject we must talk about."
Westheimer's giggly, German-accented voice, coupled with her 4-foot-7 frame, made her an unlikely looking — and sounding — outlet for "sexual literacy." The contradiction was one of the keys to her success.
But it was her extensive knowledge and training, coupled with her humorous, nonjudgmental manner, that catapulted her local radio program, "Sexually Speaking," into the national spotlight in the early 1980s. She had an open approach to what two consenting adults did in the privacy of their home.
"Tell him you're not going to initiate," she told a concerned caller in June 1982. "Tell him that Dr. Westheimer said that you're not going to die if he doesn't have sex for one week."
As a sign of her appeal across the generations and social culture, tributes came from actor-comedian Adam Sandler — "She always made us smile," he wrote on X — to New York Gov. Kathy Hochul, who appointed Westheimer the state's Ambassador of Loneliness. "May her memory be a blessing," said the governor in a statement. "She was brave, funny, candid and brilliant."
Her radio success opened new doors, and in 1983 she wrote the first of more than 40 books: "Dr. Ruth's Guide to Good Sex," demystifying sex with both rationality and humor. There was even a board game, Dr. Ruth's Game of Good Sex.
She soon became a regular on the late-night television talk-show circuit, bringing her personality to the national stage. Her rise coincided with the early days of the AIDS epidemic, when frank sexual talk became a necessity.
"If we could bring about talking about sexual activity the way we talk about diet — the way we talk about food — without it having this kind of connotation that there's something not right about it, then we would be a step further. But we have to do it with good taste," she told Johnny Carson in 1982.
She normalized the use of words like "penis" and "vagina" on radio and TV, aided by her Jewish grandmotherly accent, which The Wall Street Journal once said was "a cross between Henry Kissinger and Minnie Mouse." People magazine included her in their list of "The Most Intriguing People of the Century." She even made it into a Shania Twain song: "No, I don't need proof to show me the truth/Not even Dr. Ruth is gonna tell me how I feel."
Westheimer defended abortion rights, suggested older people have sex after a good night's sleep and was an outspoken advocate of condom use. She believed in monogamy.
In the 1980s, she stood up for gay men at the height of the AIDS epidemic and spoke out loudly for the LGBTQ community. She said she defended people deemed by some far-right Christians to be "subhuman" because of her own past.
Born Karola Ruth Siegel in Frankfurt, Germany, in 1928, she was an only child. At 10, she was sent by her parents to Switzerland to escape Kristallnacht — the Nazis' 1938 pogrom that served as a precursor to the Holocaust. She never saw her parents again; Westheimer believed they were killed in the gas chambers at Auschwitz.
At the age of 16, she moved to Palestine and joined the Haganah, the underground movement for Israeli independence. She was trained as a sniper, although she said she never shot at anyone.
Her legs were severely wounded when a bomb exploded in her dormitory, killing many of her friends. She said it was only through the work of a "superb" surgeon that she could walk and ski again.
She married her first husband, an Israeli soldier, in 1950, and they moved to Paris as she pursued an education. Although not a high school graduate, Westheimer was accepted into the Sorbonne to study psychology after passing an entrance exam.
The marriage ended in 1955; the next year, Westheimer went to New York with her new boyfriend, a Frenchman who became her second husband and father to her daughter, Miriam.
In 1961, after a second divorce, she finally met her life partner: Manfred Westheimer, a fellow refugee from Nazi Germany. The couple was married and had a son, Joel. They remained wed for 36 years until "Fred" — as she called him — died of heart failure in 1997.
After receiving her doctorate in education from Columbia University, she went on to teach at Lehman College in the Bronx. While there she developed a specialty — instructing professors how to teach sex education. It would eventually become the core of her curriculum.
"I soon realized that while I knew enough about education, I did not really know enough about sex," she wrote in her 1987 autobiography. Westheimer then decided take classes with the renowned sex therapist, Dr. Helen Singer Kaplan.
It was there that she had discovered her calling. Soon, as she once said in a typically folksy comment, she was dispensing sexual advice "like good chicken soup."
"I came from an Orthodox Jewish home so sex for us Jews was never considered a sin," she told The Guardian in 2019.
In 1984, her radio program was nationally syndicated. A year later, she debuted in her own television program, "The Dr. Ruth Show," which went on to win an Ace Award for excellence in cable television.
She also wrote a nationally syndicated advice column and later appeared in a line of videos produced by Playboy, preaching the virtues of open sexual discourse and good sex. She even had a series of calendars.
Her rise was noteworthy for the culture of the time, in which then-President Ronald Reagan's administration was hostile to Planned Parenthood and aligned with pro-conservative voices.
Phyllis Schlafly, a staunch anti-feminist, wrote in a 1999 piece "The Dangers of Sex Education," that Westheimer, as well as Gloria Steinem, Anita Hill, Madonna, Ellen DeGeneres and others were promoting "provocative sex chatter" and "rampant immorality."
Father Edwin O'Brien, the director of communications for the Catholic archdiocese of New York who would go on to become a cardinal, called her work upsetting and morally compromised.
"It's pure hedonism," O'Brien wrote in a 1982 opinion published by The Wall Street Journal. "The message is just indulge yourself; whatever feels good is good. There is no higher law of overriding morality, and there's also no responsibility."
Westheimer made appearances on "The Howard Stern Radio Show," "Nightline," "The Tonight Show," "The Ellen DeGeneres Show," "The Dr. Oz Show" and "Late Night with David Letterman." She played herself in episodes of "Quantum Leap" and "Love Boat: The Next Wave."
Her books include "Sex for Dummies," her autobiographical works "All in a Lifetime" (1987) and "Musically Speaking: A Life through Song" (2003). The documentary "Ask Dr. Ruth" aired in 2019.
During her time as a radio and television personality, she remained committed to teaching, with posts at Yale, Hunter, Princeton and Columbia universities and a busy college lecture schedule. She also maintained a private practice throughout her life.
Westheimer received an honorary doctorate from Hebrew Union College-Institute of Religion for her work in human sexuality and her commitment to the Jewish people, Israel and religion. In 2001 she received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor and the Leo Baeck Medal, and in 2004, she received the degree of Doctor of Letters, honoris causa, from Trinity College.
Ryan White, the director of "Ask Dr. Ruth," told Vice in 2019 that Westheimer was never someone following trends. She was always an ally of gay rights and an advocate for family planning.
"She was at the forefront of both of those things throughout her entire life. I met her friends from her orphanage saying even when she met gay people throughout her life in the '30s, '40s, and '50s she was always accepting of those people and always saying that people should be treated with respect."
She is survived by two children, Joel and Miriam, and four grandchildren. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports the death of Dr. Ruth Westheimer and details her life, fitting the obituary category. While it touches on health, media, and education, the primary purpose is a death notice.

title: Loveless leaves legacy of education and entrepreneurship
author: Tom McCall
content:
Loveless leaves legacy of education and entrepreneurship

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On June 15, Caroline County lost a colorful educator, politician and entrepreneur — Joe Loveless Jr. He died at 84 years old.He grew up on a farm in Finksburg and later played center on the Frostburg University football team, where he got an education degree in 1962. In 1974, Loveless got a master's in education from the same school.
In between earning his two degrees, Loveless was the athletic director at Colonel Richardson High School.
He later became the vice principal at Lockerman Middle School, and he finished his academic career at CRHS as principal.
"He was famous as a football coach, for no matter how cold it got, Joe never wore anything but a short-sleeved white shirt. He didn't want to show anybody that the cold bothered him," said Caroline County Commissioner Larry Porter.
Loveless got into politics in the early 1980s, starting as Town Commissioner of Denton, and in 1982 becoming the town's mayor.
He organized celebrity golf events at the Caroline Country Club, which brought members of the Orioles and The Baltimore Colts.
"Joe was instrumental, years ago, he would put together a celebrity golf tournament where he would have Johnny Unitas, and a group of people would come over and play golf. He had access to them because his cousin was a newscaster," Porter said. "... He would select an organization to benefit. One year it was reading programs."
"... It was a two-day event, and they would raise quite a good amount of money. Joe pulled all that together. Joe had an ability to do those things. Joe was a great guy," Porter said.
Porter said at Loveless also sold real estate and cars. He founded Joe Loveless Tires.
He was an active member of Saint Luke's Methodist Church in Denton.
"When he got involved with an activity, he worked hard. He gave it everything that he had no question about that. He benefited a lot of organizations here during his time," Porter said.
John Nussear, who went to college with Loveless, said Loveless was never short of creative ideas.
"Joe had an entrepreneurial spirit about him. He had a million ideas. He was never without an idea that he wanted to share and get other people interested in," Nussear said. "The truth about Joe was that he was salesman — a very good salesman of ideas."
Nussear thinks Loveless' main legacy is his energy.
"Energy, and ideas and a willingness to to what it takes to put an idea into action. He was very generous to a fault. He would give his last penny to someone else if he thought that they needed it," Nussear said.
According to the Baltimore Sun, plans for a private celebration of life gathering to be held in September are incomplete. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an obituary detailing the life, career in education, politics, and entrepreneurship of Joe Loveless Jr., making the Obituaries category the most appropriate primary match.

title: Charles native, killed in World War II, reinterred after eight decades
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Charles native, killed in World War II, reinterred after eight decades

 September 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fallen soldier has been laid to rest in Maryland nearly 80 years after he was killed in action overseas during World War II.U.S. Army Pfc. Lemuel Dent Jr., a native of Charles County, was interred on Sept. 5 at Cheltenham Veterans Cemetery in Prince George's County. Johnson Funeral Services of White Plains performed graveside services preceding the interment.
At the service last week, Donald Dent, Lemuel Dent's nephew, received the flag covering his family member's coffin. Lemuel Dent was survived by four sisters and five brothers, but Donald Dent said that they have since died.
"It was a surprise to me," Donald Dent said about hearing that Lemuel's remains were identified.
Prior to this, all Donald Dent knew was that his uncle had died during World War II.
Lemuel Dent was killed Feb. 8, 1945, at age 30 near the Cinquale Canal, north of Viareggio, Italy, when the tank he was aboard was struck by enemy fire.
A resident of Ironsides, an area on Route 6 in Charles County, Dent was assigned to Company L, 3rd Battalion, 366th Infantry Regiment, 92nd Infantry Division, known as the "Buffalo Soldiers" in the European Theater.
The U.S. Army recognizes the 92nd Infantry Division as the only African American infantry division to see combat in Europe during World War II.
The tank Dent was in was struck by enemy mortar, machine gun and artillery fire. His body was not recovered at the time, and the Germans never reported him a prisoner of war, the Defense POW/MIA Account Agency said in a release.
On May 5, 1945, the American Graves Registration Command, Army Quartermaster Corps, was tasked with recovering missing American personnel in the European Theater. Investigators recovered a set of remains, designated as X-124 Castelfiorentino, from a gravesite approximately 2 miles west of Pietrasanta and 500 yards north of the Cinquale Canal.
The investigators initially identified the remains as possibly belonging to a soldier of the 92nd Infantry Division but did not have enough data to make a positive identification. The remains were interred at what is now Florence American Cemetery in Impruneta, Italy.
Dent was accounted for by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency earlier this year after X-124's remains were exhumed in June 2022 from the Italian cemetery for laboratory analysis and identification.
At the funeral, local veterans and family members paid their respects to Dent. Members of the Buffalo Soldiers Motorcycle Club attended to salute Dent and pay homage to the rich history of the 92nd Infantry Division.
The name Buffalo Soldiers was initially selected for the club to pay homage to and ensure the legacy of African American military contributions in the post-Civil War era, according to the motorcycle club's website. The membership of the club is comprised of many active duty and retired service members, as well as law enforcement.
"I think it's a huge deal," Lonnie Bellamy, a member of Maryland's Buffalo Soldier chapter, said. "Taking the time to do all that work to lay him to rest, spending all that energy to put a name to the remains. … It absolutely resonated with us."
In Italy, Lemuel Dent's name is recorded on the Tablets of the Missing at Florence American Cemetery.
Now, a rosette rests alongside his name, indicating he has been accounted for and brought home. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a deceased individual, recounting his wartime service and recent reinterment, which aligns most closely with an obituary-style piece despite its historical angle.

title: Judge Wise served community, county and the law
author: Tom McCall
content:
Judge Wise served community, county and the law

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 845
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — From Caroline High School, to lawyer, to state's attorney and finally to Circuit Court judge for Caroline County, James Owen Wise was described as both fair and impartial. He served Caroline County from the bench for 17 years. He died on Wednesday, Sept 4, at 86 years old.Wise helped begin a chapter of Court Appointed Special Advocates. He saw too many children who needed advocacy as their parents went through the court system, so he did something about it.
"It was his idea definitely. He sat on the bench and heard foster care cases," said Joanne Staples, the first executive director of CASA of Caroline. "He knew what was going on and what was not going on. He could see that they needed more support than they were getting. He decided that something different needed to be done."
Something different was CASA.
"There was no doubt in his mind that it was needed and that it was the right thing to do for these children," Staples said. "He was an extremely fair person. He listened intently from all sides. He knew it from A to Z."
Wise cared about the affairs and people of Caroline County.
"We were good friends for many years. We played a lot of golf together and went on a lot of golf trips together," County Commissioner Larry Porter said. "He was an incredible advocate for the county. It is a tremendous loss to me as a friend and to the county."
Porter added, "He was the past president and assistant chief of the fire company. He was a member of the fire company until he got appointed judge. He probably had the most integrity of anybody I have ever known and at the same time was probably one of the most humble guys. He avoided saying that he was a judge."
Porter said that Wise served as judge on the police accountability board. He gave every situation a tremendous amount of thought. He was always looking at it from every angle.
Wise chaired the committee that made the decision for Caroline County to go to home rule. This gave the county the authority to enact, amend and repeal local laws, according to the Caroline County website. Porter said Wise was involved with county policy and government.
"He is one of those guys that is kind of like Forrest Gump," Porter said. "Every time you look at something, he was involved, or he knew about it. He could explain what happened."
Retired Caroline County Judge Karen Jensen succeeded Wise on the bench in 1999. She practiced as a lawyer before him as well. Wise's family asked her to speak at Wise's funeral.
"As a judge, he was always very prepared. He was always very fair. When I say 'no nonsense,' you came in and you were expected to be prepared as well as he was prepared. As a lawyer, I really enjoyed practicing in front of him," Jensen said.
She said he would come to the courthouse on his days off.
"If he was uptown going to the bank or to the post office, he just would come in and go to the clerk's office and talk to everybody. He would come up to chamber and sit down and shoot the breeze and have a cup of coffee. He was always connected with the people of Caroline County," Jensen said.
She pointed to his unique legacy of having his father as a judge too. Being a judge has its challenges.
"He never disconnected from the community, which is a hard thing to do when you are a judge," Jensen said. "When you become a judge, there is a disconnect because you have to be fair. You don't want anyone thinking you are being unduly influenced. But in a small county, it is hard to do that. He found a good balance of remaining always connected with the community and the people he loved and still maintain impartiality and fairness he needed to have."
One of the causes he was passionate about was Court Appointed Special Advocates. He has set up memorial donations to CASA of Caroline.
"Right after he retired from the bench, he founded CASA and served as the organization's first board president. He worked very closely with Joanne Staples to the develop this CASA program. She was our first executive director," said Amy Horne, current executive director of CASA of Caroline.
Horne's father served on the Talbot County Circuit Court bench while Wise served in Caroline. They were good friends, she said.
"Judge Wise was an incredibly thoughtful man. He would stop by and say hello whenever he was in town. He was always thinking of what he could do to help others, what he could do to contribute to society," Horne said.
According to Moore Funeral Home, a visitation will be held Monday, Sept. 16, from 10 until 11:30 a.m. at St. Luke's Church, 100 S. Fifth Ave. in Denton, with a memorial service following at 11:30. A reception will follow. Burial is private.
Donations may be made to CASA of Caroline Inc.: casaofcarolineinc-bloom.kindful.com or by mail to 114 Market St., Suite 100, Denton, MD 21629.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a tribute to a recently deceased judge, focusing on his life, service, and funeral details, which fits the Obituaries category best, though it also touches on local government involvement.

title: Maryland stories: Long-time community pillar turns 100
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: Long-time community pillar turns 100

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Oct. 8, Charles County welcomed its newest native centenarian, Mary Louise Booth Webb.Webb was born Oct. 8, 1924, in Bryantown.
Some of her earliest memories are from living in a one-room school as a child by the side of the road near Fort Washington National Park in Prince George's County.
After the death of Webb's mother, she moved out of the one-room schoolhouse to a 200-acre farm in Bryantown. There, she learned values that carried with her throughout her life.
"When I get up, my prayer is, 'Dear Lord, help me help those who need help the most,'" Webb told Southern Maryland News. "I think people should help each other wherever they see the need for help."
Webb's compassion and care for those in her life has been apparent to anyone that has spent time around her, as she has always been there for others in need. After her retirement from nursing in 1980, she has spent tremendous time and energy in giving others a home.
She lived in Waldorf for over 50 years, making her home welcome to guests from East Africa, victims of domestic abuse, the homeless, her family in the wake of her brother's passing and babysitting Nigerian twins until they were teenagers — to name a few of her household guests.
Those who have been under her care have kept in touch, some calling as often as weekly.
Webb has been active in her community and throughout the entire Southern Maryland region, volunteering and working in events and organizations like the American Cancer Society's Relay for Life, the Children's Aid Society's Board, the Area Council on Aging and a coordinator of National Night Out in her neighborhood.
For five decades, Webb has been an active member of the African American Heritage Society of Charles County. She is currently their oldest member and was one of the helpers in securing the African American Heritage House, which sits along the southbound lanes of Route 301 in La Plata.
"I wanted to be busy, just like now," Webb said. "I like to be busy."
She was an attendee of Bel Alton High School, which opened in 1938 when she was 14.
The Charles County Fair, which started the same year as Webb's birth, was another pleasure of hers. Webb fondly remembers her garden exhibits, where she would enter everything she possibly could.
She recalled how she was told by someone at the fair, "Everywhere I look, it's got your name on it."
One of the biggest changes that Webb has seen in the county in her lifetime was the building of infrastructure, most notably how roads and transportation developed.
Always keeping busy, Webb did not stop driving until this past February.
In 2007, Webb returned to her family's farm in Bryantown where she currently resides. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a notable local individual’s life and community contributions, a format typical of obituary or human‑interest pieces about a person, making 'Obituaries' the closest match.

title: Rich Colburn, longtime state senator and Mid-Shore politician, dies at 74
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Rich Colburn, longtime state senator and Mid-Shore politician, dies at 74

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 698
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Former state Sen. Rich Colburn died Friday in Easton at the age of 74.Colburn, a Republican, spent 28 years in Annapolis. He served as a state senator for 20 years and as a member of the House of Delegates for eight years. His district covered Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties.
After leaving office in 2015, Colburn remained involved on the Eastern Shore. He completed a 24-year stretch as the town manager for Federalsburg and was the commander of American Legion Post 91 in Cambridge.
Former colleagues and those who knew his work spoke highly of his commitment to constituent service.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said Colburn was a "fearless leader" in the statehouse. Mautz called Colburn a "relentless" politician.
"He was a master at all things Annapolis, and that was an expertise that he developed," Mautz said. "(It was) something he was willing to share with anybody that was willing to listen and learn."
"Rich was just a larger than life man who was loved by everybody in Annapolis and on the Eastern Shore," Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md) shared his condolences in a post on X Friday evening.
"Today we mourn the passing of Senator Richard Colburn who was not just a colleague, but a friend," Harris wrote. "I had the pleasure of serving with him in the Maryland State Senate and shared his passion in fighting for our watermen, farmers, Veterans and first responders."
Mautz said he's thankful to have learned from Colburn's political acumen, calling him a mentor. The current state senator said once Colburn made his mind up, "he would be undeniable in the pursuit of getting some kind of resolution to whatever it is he was working on."
In a statement on social media, the Maryland Republican Party praised the impact Colburn had on the Mid-Shore.
"His legacy as an accomplished legislator who fought hard for agriculture, conservative values, bi-partisan governance, and Eastern Shore representation, was profound and will be felt in Maryland for generations," the statement read.
Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said in a statement that Colburn "was a dedicated public servant who worked on issues big and small with thoroughness and tenacity."
"I will truly miss our rambling inside baseball conversations and his wry sense of humor as a friend," Detmer wrote, "and I will also miss his advice and mentorship as someone who is trying to follow the same path that he walked: trying to make (a) mark by trying to make a difference."
Colburn was born in Oxford and grew up on the Eastern Shore. Former Oxford Town Commissioner Jimmy Jaramillo expressed his appreciation for Colburn's mentorship in a statement.
"He was a mentor and friend who gave me my start in politics and was devoted to District 37," Jaramillo wrote. "His leadership and love for Oxford, where he was raised, and the entire district left a lasting mark on our community. I'm grateful for his guidance and support over the years."
The late senator graduated from Easton High School in 1968. After school, he joined the U.S. Army and served during the Cold War. He stayed for three years and earned the rank of sergeant.
In 1978, Colburn ran for a seat in the House of Delegates but lost. Four years later, Colburn won, beginning his political career in Annapolis. He was reelected in 1986.
His time in the House of Delegates ended in 1991. In 1994, following the retirement of longtime Democratic Sen. Frederick C. Malkus Jr., Colburn won his first Senate term.
Colburn won four additional terms before falling to Republican opponent and former state Sen. Addie Eckardt in the 2014 primary for the Senate seat.
Colburn played a large role in pushing forward many infrastructure projects on the Eastern Shore, including the Dover Bridge that connects Caroline and Talbot counties. He helped secure funding for the bridge, a process that took decades of advocacy.
Mautz says Colburn will be "sorely" missed, regardless of where political lines may fall.
"He did a lot of things and didn't ask for credit, and I think a lot of people are unaware of a lot of the good things that he's done to help people, the Eastern Shore and the state of Maryland," Mautz said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of former state senator Rich Colburn and summarizes his life and career, fitting the definition of an obituary.

title: 'A Shore Senator': Friends, colleagues reflect on contributions of the late Sen. Rich Colburn
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'A Shore Senator': Friends, colleagues reflect on contributions of the late Sen. Rich Colburn

 December 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1023
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Community members and politicians alike are reflecting on the vast impact former state Sen. Rich Colburn had on the Eastern Shore. The longtime legislator died Friday. He was 74.Colburn has been described as consistent, relentless and committed to both his work in Annapolis as a legislator and his involvement in local communities, according to family, peers and friends.
Dave Wilson, chairman of Preston Automotive Group, called Colburn a "true friend." Wilson recalled that the late senator constantly reached out, offering help and always following through.
A campaign slogan Colburn used, "A Shore Senator," promised dependability and care for the people of the region. Wilson says Colburn's life shows he made true on that promise.
"Some slogans people don't live by," Wilson said. "He lived by his. He represented everybody on the Shore."
Colburn, a Republican, spent 28 years in Annapolis. He served as a state senator for 20 years after eight years in the House of Delegates. His district covered Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties.
Former colleagues, legislators and those who knew his work spoke highly of his commitment to his constituents. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said Colburn was a "fearless leader" in the statehouse and a "relentless" politician.
"He was a master at all things Annapolis, and that was an expertise that he developed," Mautz said. "(It was) something he was willing to share with anybody that was willing to listen and learn."
CONSTITUENT SERVICEBorn in Oxford in 1950, Colburn grew up on the Eastern Shore. He graduated from Easton High School in 1968. After school, he joined the U.S. Army and served during the Cold War. He stayed for three years and earned the rank of sergeant.
The late senator worked at the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, now SuperFresh, for 25 years, and he served as Federalsburg's town manager for 24 years.
As his political career took off, he maintained connections across Mid-Shore counties. While Talbot County was his birthplace, he worked in Caroline and lived in Dorchester counties.
Jeannie Haddaway-Riccio, a former House of Delegates member who worked with Colburn while he was a senator, said he was an "incredible mentor." Haddaway-Riccio said his commitment to watermen and farmers on the Eastern Shore was unmatched.
"He really had what I would call an unrivaled work ethic, particularly when it came to fighting for his constituents and helping them with the issues that they had," she said.
Four years after his time in the House of Delegates ended, Colburn won his first Senate term, assuming the seat from the retired Democratic Sen. Frederick C. Malkus Jr. in 1995.
Len Foxwell, a veteran political and campaign strategist, worked with Colburn on multiple campaigns, but also worked for an opposing campaign during the 1994 election. Foxwell says keeping up with Colburn was impossible.
"In his prime, he was unbeatable because he simply outflanked, outhustled and outworked his opposition," Foxwell said.
Colburn won four additional terms before falling to Republican opponent and former state Sen. Addie Eckardt in the 2014 primary for the Senate seat.
Eckardt says Colburn was a master campaigner.
"He stayed out in front of his community, fighting for the very Eastern Shore conservative values," she said. "He's very persistent and intentional in what he does because he's been a real student of government and politics and history."
Colburn played a large role in pushing forward many infrastructure projects on the Eastern Shore, including the Dover Bridge that connects Caroline and Talbot counties. He helped secure funding for the bridge, a process that took decades of advocacy.
Party lines didn't slow Colburn down, colleagues say. Instead, his ability to work across the aisle and respect the process of government allowed him to successfully serve his constituents for decades.
"Nobody in elected office ever fought harder for the Eastern Shore than Rich Colburn," Foxwell said.
COMMUNITY IMPACTColburn was a consistent mentor and friend in life, many have said since his sudden death Friday.
Whether it was attending events at local fire halls, serving as post commander for American Legion Post 91 in Cambridge or rooting on his favorite baseball team, the Baltimore Orioles, Colburn was a familiar face who loved his community.
"As the Commander of the Dorchester Post 91 American Legion, he was a pillar of strength and a guiding light for all who knew him," Post 91 said in a Facebook post. "His steadfast commitment to honoring veterans and fostering unity within the Legion will never be forgotten."
"His leadership and love for Oxford, where he was raised, and the entire district left a lasting mark on our community," former Oxford Town Commissioner Jimmy Jaramillo said in a statement. "I'm grateful for his guidance and support over the years."
Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said in a statement, "I will truly miss our rambling inside baseball conversations and his wry sense of humor as a friend, and I will also miss his advice and mentorship as someone who is trying to follow the same path that he walked: trying to make (a) mark by trying to make a difference."
Colburn is survived by his wife of over 20 years, Alma Colburn, daughter Johanna Hamilton and son-in-law Bobby Hamilton, and granddaughter Saylor. Alma Colburn said 7-year-old Saylor was the joy of his life, as they often traveled to and from North Carolina to spend time with her.
Dave Wilson of Preston Automotive Group said Colburn never forgot to call him on Feb. 9, their shared birthday. Small gestures such as that yearly phone call, or their love for the Orioles, will forever be remembered.
"That's what I'm going to miss the most," Wilson said. "I'm going to miss those Feb. 9 calls."
In Wilson's experience, Colburn extended his help for issues small and large. When the Preston dealership suffered a massive fire in 2000, the state senator was one of the first to help. That knack for serving the community was never-ending, says Wilson.
"His legacy will live on," Wilson said. "He was the perfect person to represent the Shore and be part of the Shore. He just really was. When we look back on it, if there was a Hall of Fame for that, he should be in it."
This story has been updated to correct the relatives of Sen. Rich Colburn. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a tribute and reflection on the life of the recently deceased state senator, fitting the typical content of an obituary.

title: Rich Colburn, a true friend
author: Staff Writer
content:
Rich Colburn, a true friend

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 393
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Eastern Shore has lost a legend and folks across the region have lost a true friend. Having worked with Sen. Rich Colburn for more than 30 years, I believe four characteristics explain why he was so successful for so long.First, he just outworked everyone. I had the privilege of managing the 1994 State Senate campaign of his opponent, Hugh M. Smith. A typical Saturday on the hustings would consist of us arriving at every stop 25 minutes after he had been there, shaken every hand and headed for the next thing. Only to have Rich gently needle us later that day for having missed the Burrsville Ruritan Oyster Dumpling Dinner, the Greensboro Fire Department chicken BBQ or something similar. It was literally impossible to keep pace with him.
Second, nobody ever delivered better customer service and delivered better results than Rich. During my tenure at the Maryland Comptroller's Office, I received more calls from Rich than from any other trio of senators I can think of. And once he asked for help, he would hound me relentlessly to make sure I hadn't forgotten, that I was still "on it" and that it was being worked out. State officials would typically want to complete the casework just so Rich would stop bothering them. And he knew it.
Third, Rich had a Jedi-like command of what his constituents needed to hear. I will never forget a campaign forum in which he was asked about his public safety platform. Rich stood up and said the following:
"They're now talking in Washington about three strikes and you're out. I don't believe in that." And he hesitated.
The room went silent. Had Rich "gone liberal" on crime?
Then, this: "I believe in one strike and you're dead."
Bedlam erupted throughout the hall. Afterward, he pulled me aside and said, "They know I didn't mean that. People just need to hear that the politicians will keep them safe and that's how I get my point across."
Finally, Rich was an institutionalist who deeply respected the legislative process, knew bipartisan relationships were essential to getting things done in a Democratic state, and understood that was only there to make life better for the folks back home.
Rich Colburn was a man of the Shore, and he left an indelible mark on this place he so dearly loved. He will be remembered for decades to come.
LEN FOXWELL
Baltimore 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a tribute to the late Senator Rich Colburn, focusing on his life and legacy, which fits the Obituaries category. Secondary relevance to Local Government due to his political role, and a minor link to Public Safety from the quoted safety platform.

title: Ralph Bartz credits a life of activity for his 100 years
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ralph Bartz credits a life of activity for his 100 years

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Born Jan. 21, 1925, Ralph Barth celebrated 100 years of life Tuesday.Barth's family wanted to surprise him at his daughter Melinda Peugh's house on his birthday, but he knew a week before that something was going to happen.
"I had a feeling what was happening the week before that it might be something, and I expected maybe five or six people there with maybe cake and ice cream," Barth said. "But it was quite a crowd there, and I got quite a few gifts."
Dozens attended his birthday party on Sunday evening, braving the snowy weather to get there.
Barth has seen many things in 100 years, including living through World War II and surviving polio at 15 years old, which he credits, in part, for helping him reach his age.
Polio is a contagious disease that attacks the nervous system and is often fatal. For Barth, it attacked the right side of his body, leaving him in a wheelchair for a period.
Polio taught him to take his health more seriously, he said.
"I was in the University Hospital in Baltimore for about six or seven weeks," Barth said. "... and I think when you're really sick when you're younger, you respect your health more as you grow up."
Barth began his career as a 13 year-old boy in Howard County. Barth stopped going to school to help his family of 10 siblings work on their farm. His father had to go back to work to make more money because the farm wasn't making enough. Barth took over and worked the family farm until he got polio.
"I managed to farm. I did all the farm work. We had cows, horses, all kinds of chickens and poultry. And at 13, and I did all the field plowing, putting crops and things like that."
Barth had many jobs. He worked at a defense plant for the Army making copper brass. He then moved to be a lumber manager at a hardware store for 20 years, and then to the post office for 18 years.
In Barth's first marriage, he adopted two children, who he said he loves dearly.
He married his second wife, Clara Barth, on July 8, 1984. They moved to Caroline County in 1989 and opened and operated a store for 12 years. The store sold baked goods and candy, sorted mail and much more.
Barth's career didn't end until just five years ago.
"I worked in Queenstown for an estate," Barth said. "I was a carpenter helping the Kenny family build a new home on a big ranch. I also did trim work in the house, and after we finished the trim we built a new three-car garage."
Barth's stepson got him the job at the estate, but after his stepson left he stayed for another 12 years as the family's maintenance man.
"I stayed there for another 12 years after he left," Barth said. "I did maintenance work and I did outside work. I trimmed about eight acres of woods out in Lake Central Park and planted the grass and did the mowing and painted everything as maintenance on a 32 acre land."
Barth's credits his hard working mentality as the reason he has lived to 100 years old.
"All my activity, all these years, when you stay active, it's much better for you," Barth said.
He also credits a good mental outlook on life.
"I looked at the good side of everything," Barth stated. "I think the mental outlook makes a big difference in your health, too. You try to look at the good side of anything." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a profile of a centenarian focusing on his life story and legacy, fitting the typical content of an obituary. While it mentions health and farming, the primary purpose is to commemorate his life.

title: Former Rescue Fire Company Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. dies
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Former Rescue Fire Company Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. dies

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Former Fire Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. lived and breathed the Rescue Fire Company."It was definitely in his heart," said longtime friend and fellow fireman Dorchester County Council Member Ricky Travers.
Hurley, who died Jan. 23 at 68 years old, held a membership with Rescue Fire Company for 47 years, serving in a variety of roles.
He served as president from 1983 through 1985. In 1986, Hurley took on the title of first assistant chief before becoming chief for the first time in 1990. All in all, Hurley served as chief of the fire company from 1990 to 1994, from 1996 to 2002 and from 2004 to 2010.
In 2004, he was made a life member of the fire company.
Travers said Hurley was an advocate who helped move Rescue Fire Company forward.
"He fought with the city to make sure that they knew we were a part of the city and that they had to get the building permits to run through us," Travers said.
According to a social media post from Rescue Fire Company, even after his last term as chief, Hurley would still show up to fire incidents from time to time, sharing his expertise with firemen.
"My phone rang once or twice a week with him," said current Rescue Fire Chief Brad Walters, laughing.
Walters, who in his first years with the company worked under Hurley, said Hurley was a "strong-willed" leader who fought for what the department needed.
"He was the cornerstone of where we are and how we operate now," Walters said. "Every piece of apparatus inside the fire house at this time has his name attached to it in some manner. Whether he was on the committee, whether he was the chief overseeing it. Specifically, some of the engines. He fought extremely hard with the city to purchase the needed equipment for our department."
Walters said Hurley was also "kind hearted." He said he remembers Hurley helping him out and giving him side jobs when he was younger.
"He was there to make sure everyone excelled around him," Walters said.
Hurley served his community in more ways than one. He spent his career at Jess Jr's & Son's, a collision repair shop and towing service in Cambridge. He served in multiple positions as a member of the Cambridge Yacht Club, ultimately becoming the club's commodore.
His involvement spanned from the Cambridge Rotary Club, to the Maryland State Firefighters Association, to the Maryland Fire Chiefs Association to the Towing and Recovery Professionals of Maryland.
"He was a leader in the community," Travers said.
Hurley will be remembered for his friendship. Martin Pepper, who met Hurley in 1986 and served multiple years as assistant chief when Hurley was chief, said Hurley was very important to him.
"He was a very good friend to me," Pepper said. "Good friend to a lot of people, but we were very close."
During a Cambridge City Council meeting on Jan. 27, Commission President Sputty Cephas talked about his friendship with Hurley.
"There wasn't a time that we couldn't go to Jeff for whatever," he said, later adding, that Hurley will "truly" be missed.
Hurley is survived by his son, Jeffery O. Hurley Jr. (Sarah); bonus sons Joshua Bauguess (Kayla) and Noah Bauguess (Deanna); brother Jed M. Hurley Sr. (Brenda); nephew Jed "J.R." Hurley Jr. (Abbie); niece Amanda Jo Hurley Hallowell (Logan); great nieces Abriella Hallowell, Leilani Hallowell and Maddie Hurley; great nephew Jed M. Hurley III and God children Brandon Hall, JR Moore and Maddie Fleming.
Hurley is preceded in death by his parents, daughter Jessica Anne Hurley and his brother, Jay L. Hurley.
Services will be held Friday, Jan. 31. A visitation will be held from 10 a.m. to noon at the Public Safety Building at 8 Washington St. in Cambridge. The visitation will be followed by a firefighter memorial service at noon at the Public Safety Building. After that, a brief procession will pass by Jess Jr's & Son's and the old fire house at 307 Gay St. before entering Dorchester Memorial Park for burial services. A wake will be held after the burial at the East New Market Volunteer Fire Department. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of a former fire chief and details his life, family, and funeral arrangements, which fits the definition of an obituary. While it relates to public safety and mentions city council interactions, the primary purpose is a death notice.

title: 'Mrs. Hollis was my compass,’ my true north': Pioneering educator and community activist dies at 97
author: DOUG BISHOP
content:
'Mrs. Hollis was my compass,’ my true north': Pioneering educator and community activist dies at 97

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Madelyn Matthews Hollis, 97, a dedicated educator who taught for more than three decades in Queen Anne's County schools and became a steadfast community advocate, died Thursday, Feb. 20, while under care at Compass Hospice in Centreville.Born in Accomack County, Virginia, Hollis arrived in Centreville in 1948 when she was hired by then-Superintendent Harry Rhodes to teach mathematics at Kennard High School, which served African American students during segregation.
Hollis taught at Kennard until 1966, when segregation ended in Queen Anne's County. She then transferred to Queen Anne's County High School, where she taught mathematics and driver's education until her retirement in 1981 after 33 years in education.
"She was a really good teacher," said former student Naimbi Davis of Centreville. "She was not a coddler with students. However, she knew how to teach them. Math was never my subject, but Mrs. Hollis taught me the essentials."
Beyond her teaching career, Hollis was deeply involved in community service. She was an active member of New Life United Methodist Church in Centreville and served as president of the Lucretia Kennard Homemaker's Club for at least 16 years.
Perhaps her most enduring legacy came through her fierce advocacy to preserve the former Kennard High School building when it faced demolition after closing. That preservation effort, spearheaded by Hollis and carried forward by alumni, culminated in the 2019 dedication of the Kennard African American Cultural Center and Museum.
Clayton Washington, who led the alumni restoration efforts, said, "Mrs. Hollis was 'my compass,' my true north. She kept me on point. She always told me, 'Boy, don't start something you can't finish!' When we dedicated the Kennard African American Center in May 2019, I was pleased I could say to her, 'We got it done!' I know she was happy."
From 1985 to 1995, Hollis served on the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board, appointed by then-Maryland Governor Harry Hughes. During her tenure, she was instrumental in establishing Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday as a school holiday in the county.
Former board colleague Elizabeth Broderick described Hollis as "an icon of the community" who "went to college earning her teaching degree when going to college was not open to everyone, especially African American women."
Hollis was known for her strong Christian faith and believed that prayer in schools taught students respect for "a higher being" that could be applied to all aspects of life.
Her former classroom at the Kennard African American Cultural Center features her picture, her name, and writing on the blackboard in her handwriting—a tribute to "living history."
"She was one of my favorite teachers," said Jim Brown, a Kennard High School graduate and former Grasonville Community Center President. "I'd say she was a very kind Christian lady, who was devoted to her church, Kennard, and her work with the NAACP. I say she was a community activist."
A Celebration of Life will be held later in March. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of a longtime teacher and community activist, functioning primarily as an obituary while also highlighting her contributions to education.

title: Former Cambridge Police Chief Russell Wroten dies
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Former Cambridge Police Chief Russell Wroten dies

 April 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 543
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Those who served under former Cambridge Police Chief Russell Wroten during his 30-year term know he was passionate about law enforcement and ensuring the safety of Cambridge."It takes toughness and willingness to enforce the law and bring the criminals to justice (so) people feel safe in their community," said Thomas Hurley, the president of the Fraternal Order of Police Cambridge Dorchester Lodge 27. "And Russell Wroten was about that."
Wroten, who retired from the police department in 2001, died Monday in Easton. He was 84 years old.
Wroten served with the department for 38 years, 30 of which as chief. Hurley, who served under Wroten for many years, said Wroten stood up to crime and stood up for his officers.
"He did a lot for this department, and he was there a long time," Hurley said. "He did make a difference in the City of Cambridge."
Current Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd remembers Wroten as someone who took his job seriously and knew the city "like the back of his hand."
Todd remembers being less than a year into the job when Wroten pulled Todd into his office to tell him he was retiring and share his thoughts on what Todd needed to do to have a successful career.
"Him taking that time to say that to me, who — I'm brand new, definitely carried with me throughout the years," Todd said, adding the experience illustrated Wroten's leadership.
Last year, Wroten was recognized as the first inductee into the Cambridge Police Department Hall of Fame. Todd said he was the first person who came to mind when the department decided it wanted to begin recognizing officers.
"I mean, 30 years as the chief of police, he saw a lot of officers come and go," Todd said. "He saw the racial riots. He saw Cambridge at its worst. And we just thought that that definitely needed to be recognized."
Serving the department through multiple decades, Wroten saw good times and tumultuous times in Cambridge. During a time of civil unrest Cambridge experienced in July 1967, Wroten — who was an officer at that time — was shot while investigating a broken window at a laundromat in the 2nd Ward. The incident caused the police chief at the time, Brice Kinnamon, to order the ward be sealed off by police.
Following Kinnamon, Wroten became chief four years later.
Hurley said although Wroten was well-respected, law enforcement officials often face criticism. "But he took care of the job," Hurley said. "He took care of the city."
A graduate of the FBI Academy, Wroten received multiple awards and citations in his career, according to his obituary.
Outside of his career, Wroten was a member of multiple organizations, including Cambridge Masonic Lodge 66, Rescue Fire Company and Cambridge Elks Lodge 1272.
According to his obituary, Russell is survived by his wife of 62 years Regina Wroten of East New Market, their daughter Christina "Chrissy" and son-in-law Tom Thompson of Cambridge, granddaughter Savana "Jon" Linthicum of Rhodesdale, great-granddaughter Arya, several nephews and a niece.
Wroten's funeral will be held Tuesday, April 22, at Newcomb and Collins Funeral Home in Cambridge. Visitation will be from 11 a.m. until 1 p.m. The service, which will include the city police honor guard, will begin at 1 p.m. Burial will be in East New Market. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily announces the death and funeral details of a former police chief, fitting the obituary category, while also relating to public safety and local government contexts.
