title: Robert Earl Price, poet, playwright and arts advocate dies
author: Staff Writer
content:
Robert Earl Price, poet, playwright and arts advocate dies

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Robert Earl Price, a celebrated poet, playwright, and champion of African American culture, died April 16 at the age of 83. Price, a former screenwriter during the Black Arts Movement and an influential figure in the arts community, spent the final 18 years of his life in Chestertown, where he co-founded the Kent County Poetry Festival, worked extensively with the Kent Cultural Alliance and contributed to preserving local African American history.Price was a prolific writer with several books of poetry, including "Wise Blood" and "Blood Flow", the latter of which earned him the William Meredith Award. His work transcended genres, with over a dozen of his plays produced, including notable works like "Blue Monk", which was commissioned for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. His plays were performed internationally, with productions in Johannesburg, Berlin, and across the United States.
Price's career spanned several decades and locations. Born in Atlanta, Georgia, he studied at Clark Atlanta University and later moved to Los Angeles, where he joined the Black Arts Movement and contributed to the L.A. Rebellion. He received the prestigious William Wyler Fellowship for Screenwriting from the American Film Institute, and collaborated with well-known figures such as Norman Lear and Alex Haley on the TV series "Palmerstown, U.S.A." His work earned him an NAACP Image Award and recognition for his activism, including co-founding the Black Anti-Defamation Coalition in 1980.
In addition to his achievements in screenwriting and theater, Price was a dedicated educator. He served as Artist-in-Residence at Washington College in Chestertown, where he wrote and produced two new plays. His work also contributed to understanding slavery during the Revolutionary Era, particularly through productions such as "The Unlading", a work that gave better perception of the role of slavery in Eastern Shore history.
Price's poetry and plays often incorporated jazz and blues, blending these musical forms with themes of resistance and social justice. His work explored African American history, celebrated cultural icons, and pushed the boundaries of traditional theater. His friends and colleagues remember him for his sharp wit, deep wisdom, and unwavering belief in the power of art to challenge the status quo.
Christopher Ames, president emeritus of Russell Sage College, worked with Price in both Atlanta and Chestertown. "I first met Robert Earl when I was serving on the board of 7Stages, the innovative theater company in Atlanta, where he was the Playwright in Residence. Later, when I moved to Chestertown to serve as Provost and Dean at Washington College, I was thrilled to hire Robert Earl as a part-time Artist in Residence in the Drama Department," Ames said. "He and his wife embraced this community, and Robert Earl's impact was immediate and lasting. Together, we conceived the Kent County Poetry Festival with the help of Tom Martin and The Book Plate. Robert Earl was not just a co-founder; he was the heartbeat of the festival, present and actively organizing every year until this last April, when he was on his deathbed. His passion for poetry, community, and the arts was unmatched, and his legacy will continue to influence the festival and the arts scene here for years to come."
A devoted father and grandfather, Price is survived by his partner of 33 years, Carol Colgate; three children, Dhati Price, Makini Jones (Elzia), and Mshinda Jones (Lisa); five grandchildren, Ariana, Phylicia, Philip, Jamal, and Bashiri Halan; and one great-grandson, Brayden.
A memorial service will be held in Chestertown June 21.
Price's legacy as a poet, playwright, and cultural advocate will continue to inspire and shape the Eastern Shore arts community for years to come. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of poet/playwright Robert Earl Price and summarizes his life, fitting the obituary category, while also relating to arts and entertainment.

title: A story of sacrifice: Sergeant's service long remembered
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
A story of sacrifice: Sergeant's service long remembered

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 990
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Lifelong Betterton resident and historian Larry Crew stands at the foot of three gravestones in the golden light of waning day at Still Pond Cemetery, reflecting.One stone is his father's, Larry Sr. He was a merchant marine, and often regaled Crew with stories of surviving storms and torpedoes in World War II. Next to him lies Stephen J. Crew, brother.
Beside Stephen, with American flag fluttering and a wreath, lies the stone of Crew's younger brother, U.S. Army Sergeant Carl Joseph Crew, who lost his life defending his nation in Vietnam March 24, 1969.
Like many who fought that war, Carl never gave his brother or family a full report on what he did as part of the U.S. Army Americal Division after finishing his training at Fort Bragg, North Carolina.
But Crew, the older brother, attending the University of Baltimore at the time for business, was wise enough to read between the lines of the letters Carl sent back each week in 1968-1969. While his letters described the landscape and countryside innocently enough, the pictures provided the truth.
"They were just soldiers in a line, in jungles, fields, walking the countryside, waiting to get shot at," Crew said.
Sgt. Carl Crew told his grandmother even less not wanting her to worry, writing to her that he "spends a lot of time on the beach." His immediate family knew better. They knew there were young soldiers dying from Kent County in the war combined with that sense of foreboding those pictures spoke of to Crew.
His family seemed to know it would just be a matter of time. "You just counted the days," Crew said.
It came. One day, Crew said he and his family were in their house at the center of town when an ordinary car pulled up and a uniformed soldier made their way toward them. Crew does not remember who it was — just the woeful message he delivered.
Carl was killed before his 21st birthday which would have been Aug. 5, 1969.
His brother's funeral, Crew noted, practically drew out the entire town.
To Kent County he was not known as sergeant, he was known as Carl, an adventurous youth, great with mechanics, a charismatic outdoorsman who loved hunting fishing and especially guns, and wanted to stay in Kent County to enjoy the simple life.
Crew remembered his brother's ambition, working jobs while still in school. He worked at Newsome's Garage the auto shop in Betterton and the butcher shop at the A&P, close to Philosopher's Terrace in Chestertown, now the Dollar General.
"His whole life was here," Crew said.
Crew, who always sensed Carl was involved in something more dangerous than he let on, got confirmation of that from one of his brother's war comrades who wrote to him. In the letter, this gentleman said Carl was their M-60 gunner, which put a huge target on his back for the enemy.
The operator of the devastating M-60 had to hold the weapon's weight at 23 pounds plus the weight of the belt of cartridges where a belt of 100 rounds weighed 7 pounds. When the weapon was deployed, it took down everything in its path, soldiers, tunnels, trees, the whole forest line. So when the enemy spotted a M-60 gunner, their primary goal was to attack him first, much like a sniper in the trees thought about officers.
It was these deadly conditions that Carl lived out daily. "Everywhere he went they tried to take him out," Crew surmised.
His brother who loved guns, mechanics, adventure, and learned skills quickly, would have excelled with the weapon, and built stocky and strong, would have been able to carry it efficiently.
And although Crew has no records of his brother's platoon's conflicts, Carl must have been highly valued, going from the rank of E-1 to sergeant in less than a year, Crew stated.
Although Carl is not mentioned specifically, the Americal Division is unique and special in itself. It was one of two divisions not numbered, formed in World War II, 1942 on the island of New Caledonia. Then it was reformed during Vietnam as the Americal ("American, New Caledonian Division") or 23rd Infantry Division, which it was rarely called.
In World War II, it was the first United States Army unit to conduct an offensive operation against the enemy in either the Pacific or European Theaters of Operation. The Americal Division was described as the most effective of all the U.S. Army divisions on Guadalcanal, some historians noted.
After being inactivated for a time, they were reactivated in Vietnam with a mission to operate in close cooperation with the 1st Marine Division in South Vietnam.
During their six-year deployment in Nam, Americal engaged in jungle warfare and was reported to have never lost a major battle. But those wins came with high costs. According to statistics,, American KIA's for the Americal infantry brigades in Vietnam were: 196th LIB (1,188), 11th LIB (1,109), 198th LIB (987), 199th LIB (757).
Of the 987, Carl was one of those.
During that night battle March, 1969, Sergeant Carl Joseph Crew lost his life, as reported from several military sites, through "hostile action...multiple fragmentation wounds." The incident location was in South Vietnam, the Quang Tin province.
Attached to 198th Light Infantry Brigade, 1st Battalion, 6th Infantry, B Company, he received the purple heart and other accommodations throughout his short military career.
But these military records, although decorated, do not tell the complete picture of his experiences.
Crew said he often walks past the graves and as many do, thinks what life would have been if his brother were alive today. He thinks what if Carl was not a casualty of a night attack and returned to Betterton, to the place he loved, where he always wanted to stay.
As Memorial Day approaches, Crew tells the story of his brother as a way to remember those other officers in Still Pond Cemetery and cemeteries around the nation. The stories of the soldiers that were not told in their entirety, like his brother's, does not lessen their sacrifice. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a memorial piece recounting the life and military service of a deceased individual, fitting the obituary category.

title: Former Federalsburg Mayor William Beall dies
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Former Federalsburg Mayor William Beall dies

 June 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Former Federalsburg Mayor William "Bill" Beall died Friday, June 13, just after 5 p.m., according to his family.Beal is remembered by friends and family for his dedication to the town. He was elected to his first term as mayor in September 2011 and was reelected to a second term in September 2013.
"My dad was a great man," Beall's son, Ben Beall, said. "He loved this town, and he loved just being able to find ways to to make it better for the people. He was never a man about himself or fortune or fame. He just wanted to do the right thing for the people in the community."
Current Federalsburg Councilwoman Brandy James said she would get emails from Beall with advice on running the town.
Beall grew up in Texas. He majored in business administration and minored in marketing at Texas State University before he was recruited by the Dixie Cup division of the American Can Company. Beall was a sales representative in a number of cities and states before being promoted to district manager in the Baltimore/Washington area. From there, he was promoted to manager at corporate headquarters in Greenwich, Conn.
After 21 years with Dixie Cup, he took early retirement and was vice president of a national sales and marketing company. In 2002, he was recruited as a sales representative for Oakwood Homes in Delaware. Shortly afterward, he was promoted to general manager for its Jacksonville, North Carolina location. A reorganization sent Beall back to Federalsburg, where he was a senior energy analyst with Atlantic Energy Resources.
Beall and his wife, Madeline, were married for 60 years, they would've celebrated 61 years together on the Fourth of July. They met when they were 14 years old. She said he waited until he was able to drive to take her on their first date.
"We were driving down the Main Street in Austin, Texas, and we drove we past the funeral home there, and he said, 'People are just dying to get in there,' and I thought that was so funny. He could always make me laugh," Madeline Beall said. "Humor and laughter is a big part of our family and our friends."
Ben Beall remembered the time he went with his father to spring training to see their favorite team, the New York Yankees.
"We were big baseball fans and love the New York Yankees, and he brought me to Fort Lauderdale for spring training," Ben Beall said. "I was 10 years old, and we went to a few games. He booked us at the the same hotel that the Yankees were staying at. So I got like 20 autographs, and I was just on Cloud 9. He just made it a really special weekend for me."
Beall's daughter Rebecca Beall-Ochsner remembered her father for all the work he did in Federalsburg for children.
"He was a huge advocate for kids," Ochsner said. "One of my fondest memories of coming to visit is when he bought really nice shirts and pants for some kiddos in the neighborhood to wear to church and gave them Bibles, and I think that that influenced them." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of a former mayor and details his life, fitting the obituary category, though it also relates to local government.

title: 'The best of us': Montana cowboy poet Wally McRae dead at 89
author: Amanda Eggert Montana Free Press
content:
'The best of us': Montana cowboy poet Wally McRae dead at 89

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Amanda Eggert Montana Free Press | Section: News 
 
 1037
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cowboy poet Wallace "Wally" McRae of Colstrip died June 22 at the age of 89. McRae gained fame in Montana — and across the country — for the resonance of his voice and the causes he furthered with it.The youngest of three children, McRae grew up steeped in cowboy culture and was drawn to entertaining from a young age. He found success in both arenas. In 2020, he was inducted into the Montana Cowboy Hall of Fame. A long list of statewide and national organizations recognized McRae's creative contributions, including the National Endowment for the Arts.
In a 2018 interview with Andy Hedges, McRae recounted how at 4-years-old, he recited a little poem at a local Christmas program that was so warmly received it left a lasting impression. "I mean — it was showtime," he said. "I was a hero. The lights came up. The microphone got live and I was addicted to poetry from that time on."
After graduating from Colstrip High School, he enrolled in Montana State University, where he was president of his class and earned a degree in zoology. Shortly thereafter, McRae joined the Navy, which took him to the Mediterranean and his future wife. McRae married Ruth Hayes, a nurse from Pennsylvania, in 1960. They raised one son, Clint, and two daughters, Allison and Natalie, on a cattle ranch near the one McRae's grandfather owned.
McRae used his affinity for speaking and writing in a variety of venues. He worked as a rodeo announcer, penned four books of poetry and one of prose, and acted, directed and wrote plays for the Coal and Cattle Country Players theater group in Colstrip.
For decades, he used his voice, both literally and figuratively, to advocate for family ranches and the land and water critical to them. He engaged in a protracted battle with the energy developers who sought to transform Colstrip into a sprawling industrial zone to power the country, using his poetry to describe the companies' tactics to garner access to the coal beneath ranchers' land and the landscapes and community ties at stake.
In 1984, McRae helped launch the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering in Elko, Nevada. He became a fixture at the event, attending it every year for 35 years. In 1990, he became the first cowboy poet — and the first Montanan — to become a National Heritage Fellow, an honor presented by the Washington, D.C.,-based National Endowment for the Arts.
"People didn't realize it, but cowboys were one of the few surviving occupational groups that still dealt in poetry," he said in an interview his alma mater published in 2009. "Sailors and loggers and farmers and military personnel all have left a history of writing poetry, but for some reason they quit. We didn't."
Stephanie Davis, a songwriter who first met McRae at one of the early National Cowboy Poetry Gatherings, said he may have cultivated a "cowboy curmudgeon" image, "but underneath that, he was a giant marshmallow."
Davis said McRae donated the National Endowment for the Arts prize money — $10,000 — to support the Montana Cowboy Poet Gathering. McRae's generosity helped Davis, who was living in Nashville at the time, return to her beloved home state of Montana to perform.
"I thought that was extraordinary: you win something and donate it right away to somebody else," she said, going on to describe him as a man who "contained multitudes."
"I don't think he had a TV. I think he had shelves of books. He and his wife, Ruth, just read," Davis said. "He was just the best of us: the best of Montana, the best poet. It's a huge loss."
Teresa Erickson, a Billings resident who led the Northern Plains Resource Council from 1985 to 2019, described McRae as one of the organization's earliest and strongest advocates for family agricultural operations.
Erickson said the willingness of McRae and others to push back on mining companies' hunger for southeastern Montana coal moved the needle on several issues. Northern Plains prevailed in their nearly four-decades-long fight to stop a railroad from being built to transport Powder River Basin coal through southeastern Montana. In a similar vein, Erickson said coalbed methane production, which she described as a "disastrous" prospect for southeastern Montana landowners, "never really took off in Montana" due in part to the efforts of McRae and others.
"He loved Colstrip and loved eastern Montana," Erickson said. "He loved the prairie very, very much and saw the beauty of it. Not everybody's like that."
Erickson attributes some of McRae's charisma to his voice. She said he had
"the quintessential Marlboro man" voice, which may have been related, she said, to McRae's fondness for cigarettes. Erickson said McRae's integrity also made a lasting impression on her and others.
Erickson recalled McRae's confrontation with a coal company employee who'd surreptitiously squirreled away some Northern Plains-produced fact sheets ahead of a meeting with the Northern Cheyenne tribe, the Bureau of Land Management and residents impacted by nearby coal-mining operations.
"He stood for truly conservative principles in the purest form of what that means — and not the political sense."
Jim Jensen, former Montana Environmental Information Center executive director
"Wally just marched right up to [the coal company representative] and said, 'Give me back those fact sheets right now.' The guy denied it, and he said, 'We saw you take them.' The guy very sheepishly handed them over to him," Erickson recalled. "There was just something about that act. He wasn't afraid, and he had a moral code, which was: You don't lie to people. You're honest."
Jim Jensen, former Montana Environmental Information Center executive director, first met McRae in the late 1970s while learning about coal development in Colstrip as a graduate student at the University of Montana. Jensen said McRae offered an eloquent "perspective about what was before, what was coming, and what was worth saving."
"I loved Wally McRae," Jensen said. "He stood for truly conservative principles in the purest form of what that means — and not the political sense."
In "My Requiem," a poem McRae recited in his 2018 conversation with Hedges, he offered this aspiration:
"Some would build an edifice
An architectural gem
To serve throughout the ages
As a lasting requiem
But grant to me this final wish
When I say that last amen
May my mark be carried lightly
In the hearts and minds of men." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily serves as an obituary, detailing the death, life achievements, and legacy of cowboy poet Wally McRae. While it highlights his contributions to poetry and cultural events (Arts & Culture), the main purpose is to announce and commemorate his passing.

title: He 'loved this town': Easton community remembers Darren Foxwell
author: Konner Metz
content:
He 'loved this town': Easton community remembers Darren Foxwell

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Inside the Easton High School auditorium on Wednesday, current and former students, teachers and community members gathered. It had barely been a month since seniors walked across the auditorium's stage, received their diplomas and turned their tassels toward the next stage of life. Wednesday's event was a sharp contrast.Family, friends and Easton High students and staff joined together to remember recent graduate Darren Foxwell at a funeral service and, later that day, a celebration of life at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Throughout the day, many remarked how kind, caring and genuine of a person Foxwell was.
Former Principal Sherry Spurry reflected on Foxwell's four years at Easton High while giving a eulogy at the funeral. She commended the honor roll student for his academic talents and especially emphasized his top-notch character.
"He was a beacon of light and joy to everyone who knew him," Spurry said. "He was kind and carried a spirit that was infectious. He brought laughter and warmth to every room that he entered. His kindness had no bounds, and he had this uncanny ability to make everyone feel valued, seen and loved."
On June 17, Foxwell, 18, was a passenger in a single-car crash outside Trappe. He was transported to Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment of life-threatening injuries. He died the next day.
In the days since, family, friends and the entire Easton community have grappled with the loss of the recent graduate, also a member of the school's wrestling and lacrosse teams. This fall, Foxwell planned to attend Bethany College in West Virginia to play lacrosse.
Former classmates and teammates say they rarely saw Foxwell sad. He was known for his "signature ear-to-ear grin" — as his older sister, Colleen, said at the funeral Wednesday — and his cheerful greetings in the school hallways.
Wrestling teammate Khadija Popam, a rising sophomore, said Foxwell took time out of a free day earlier this year to watch her compete at a meet in Queen Anne's County. When she won her match, he was "ecstatic" for Popam, telling her to never doubt herself.
Older classmates and teammates were impacted by him, too. Matthew Svehla, a 2024 Easton graduate and former wrestling team captain, said Foxwell, even as a junior, made him a better leader.
"Without him, I wouldn't have been able to work as hard as I did," Svehla said.
At the funeral service, Foxwell's lacrosse teammates sported #17 armbands above their elbows. Hundreds attended, from family and friends to local and state elected officials.
Colleen Foxwell, Spurry and Darren's former Little League assistant coach Wade Dressler delivered speeches. Peter Hyman, rabbi emeritus at Temple B'nai Israel, officiated.
Colleen spoke about her brother's quick-witted humor and how he truly came into himself during his teenage years, growing not just tall, but confident. He was always humble, though, and would treat everyone with kindness, she said.
"Anyone who knows Darren and I knows we were not just brother and sister. We were best friends from the day that he was born," she said.
Darren Foxwell is survived by his parents, Len Foxwell and Kerry Daly; sister, Colleen; maternal grandparents, Jerry and Linda Daly; maternal grandmother, Janice Foxwell; and aunts, uncles and cousins.
Colleen said Wednesday that the family is thankful for the community's overwhelming support.
"Outpour is an absolute understatement for the amount of love and support that we have felt from each and every one of you," she said.
A common theme surfaced during both the funeral and the celebration of life: carrying on Darren's legacy. Spurry and Colleen Foxwell asked the Easton High School community to do just that.
"While we are all mourning this devastating loss of Darren today, and we will continue to for a really long time, let's remember the joy and laughter that he brought into each one of our lives," Spurry said. "Let's remember the memories, appreciate the little moments and embrace life with passion."
"Help us carry on my brother's legacy," Colleen Foxwell said. "Help out your neighbor, smile at a stranger, pick up a piece of trash you see on the ground, play peekaboo with the baby staring at you in the checkout line. As cliche as it sounds, do something nice when nobody's looking.
"My brother loved this town so much. He loved each and every one of you. And we will absolutely never forget the way that you all stood by our side." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a memorial/obituary for a local high‑school graduate, focusing on his life, death, and community remembrance, which aligns directly with the Obituaries topic.

title: Ellen Rajacich, a community legend
author: Staff Writer
content:
Ellen Rajacich, a community legend

 July 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Having called Talbot County home for over 20 years now, I've had the blessing of hearing the stories of past leaders who transformed Talbot County into the loving community we enjoy today. The list of those who built this place we call home reads as a "who's who" of servant leaders: Nettie Jones, Shirley Gooch, Maggie Farree, Tom Hill, Mike Menzies, Bill Ryan, Richard Marks, Eric Lowery, Dick Bodorff, Blenda Armistead, Bette Kenzie, Delia Denny and so many more.Today, I want to honor the life of one of those incredible people — Ellen Rajacich — a true legend in every sense of the word.
Ellen was a YMCA volunteer for more than 50 years. She touched the lives of thousands through her group exercise classes, her time in the pool, on the water at the Tred Avon Yacht Club and her tireless service throughout our community. Her energy, warmth and passion made a lasting impact wherever she went.
Personally, Ellen had a profound impact on my life. Twenty years ago, as the new CEO of the YMCA of Talbot County, I was only 34 — new to the job and still learning. Ellen welcomed me with open arms and quickly showed me the importance of the work the Y, to always be ready for company and work tirelessly to improve the quality of the life of those we're fortunate enough to serve.
As the Y grew and I found myself in the Easton Y a little less, she always took time for me. With a warm smile and kind hug her favorite question for me was always, "And what are we doing to take care of ourselves?" — a gentle nudge from someone who truly cared.
Ellen embodied love, service, strength and joy. Her legacy will live on through Talbot County for generations to come.
Fair winds and following seas, Mrs. Rajacich. We'll see each other again down the road.
ROBBIE GILL
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a tribute honoring the life and community contributions of Ellen Rajacich, fitting the typical content of an obituary.

title: Kathy Wright, tireless youth advocate, dies in Queen Anne’s County
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Kathy Wright, tireless youth advocate, dies in Queen Anne’s County

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 608
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kathy Wright, a longtime advocate for substance abuse prevention and youth education in Queen Anne's County, died July 8. She was a driving force behind numerous local initiatives focused on protecting and empowering young people, and her death leaves a profound void in the community she served with compassion and resolve.Among her many roles, Wright was assistant director with the QAC Drug Free Coalition and was instrumental in forming and leading the QAC SafeHomes Program — a coalition effort among the county's health department, public schools and local organizations to prevent underage substance use. Her email address, once listed on SafeHomes materials, served as the contact point for countless families seeking guidance.
Wright was a key figure in linking school-based prevention with broader community outreach, including the Safe Youth campaign, which saw a 50 percent reduction in 30-day binge drinking rates among local students.
"It is going to take a coordinated school and community approach to change these established youth drinking patterns," Wright said at the time. "The Drug Free Queen Anne's Coalition has been working to mobilize the community to address alcohol and other substance use for the last four years."
She co-chaired the Queen Anne's County Youth Summit and played an active role in the federally funded QAC SAFe Youth Campaign and its supporting activities, including organizing educational materials for prom and graduation, and speaking at community forums like the "Community in Crisis" panel in 2020.
"It's everyone's responsibility," Wright once said. "We are asking all community members to help us reduce access. Be the wall between teens and alcohol."
Wright's involvement extended to the Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition, where she and her husband, Warren Wright, were recognized with the Points of Light Presidential Award in 2018 for their years of work in youth drug prevention. The couple was regularly seen supporting local youth programs, including Drug-Free Student Ambassadors and the annual QAC Goes Purple campaign, a communitywide initiative for substance abuse awareness.
"Kathy Wright was a true champion for our community," said Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann.
"Her unwavering dedication to intertwining community health prevention programs with law enforcement has left a lasting impact on our community," Hofmann said. "Through her efforts in addressing alcohol, tobacco, and substance use, she fostered a collaborative spirit that brought together a diverse community for the greater good."
The sheriff said that Wright's vision and commitment to prevention empowered individuals and strengthened the community's resolve to face challenging issues in partnership with the Sheriff's Office.
"She will be deeply missed, but her legacy of compassion and partnership will continue to inspire us all," he said
Julie Kille, opioid education and prevention coordinator for Queen Anne's County Public Schools, reflected on her colleague's influence.
"It is with heavy hearts that we remember and honor the life of a remarkable individual, Kathy Wright," Kille said. "Her legacy will continue to shine brightly in the lives she touched."
Calling Wright's commitment "powerful and profoundly effective," Kille called her friend "a guiding light for youth and families across our county."
"For years, she dedicated herself to educating others about the dangers of substance abuse, never wavering in her mission to protect and uplift the next generation," she said. "To so many, Kathy was not just an advocate, she was a friend. She saw people, truly saw them, and made them feel valued. Her warm presence, her steadfast belief in the good of others, and her ability to lift people up will be sorely missed."
Wright's work touched every corner of Queen Anne's County — from school hallways to government panels — and her legacy continues in the lives she helped shape and the programs she helped build.
Information on services will be shared when available.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces the death of Kathy Wright and highlights her life and contributions, fitting the primary purpose of an obituary. While it touches on health, education, and public safety initiatives, the central focus is the notice of her passing.

title: Stories tell a lot about former Easton police chief
author: Staff Writer
content:
Stories tell a lot about former Easton police chief

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 235
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Family stories tell a lot about people and the lives they live.Reporter Konner Metz sat down this week with the wife and children of former Easton Police Chief R. Edward "Eddy" Blessing and heard many stories.
They were stories of Blessing's lifelong commitment to family, law enforcement and the town he called home.
Blessing, Easton's eighth police chief, died Aug. 17. He was 84.
One story stood out in my mind. It was a story that told about Blessing, but it also told about his wife's dedication to and love of her husband.
Donna was in labor with the couple's youngest child, Billy. It was July 7, 1980, and Eddy was being sworn in as police chief. The town moved his swearing-in up to the start of the meeting that evening. Blessing was sworn in, and they quickly departed for the hospital.
"I was already in labor, but I refused to miss it," Donna said.
That story tells much about the family, their love for each other and their dedication to the Town of Easton.
Read Konner's story at the link below. It is filled with more stories from the family and his colleagues remembering his lifelong commitment to family, law enforcement and the town he called home.
Also in today's newspaper are stories about Talbot County teachers celebrating their opening day of school and Dorchester students facing more restrictions on their use of cell phones at school this year.
— Jim Johnson

title: Longtime Easton police chief remembered for dedication
author: Konner Metz
content:
Longtime Easton police chief remembered for dedication

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 543
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton community and family members are remembering former Police Chief R. Edward "Eddy" Blessing for his lifelong commitment to family, law enforcement and the town.Blessing, Easton's eighth police chief, died Aug. 17. He was 84.
Blessing spent 31 years at the Easton Police Department, the place he started his law enforcement career in 1964. He was appointed chief in 1980 and led the agency for 15 years.
His wife, Donna, fondly recalled her husband's swearing-in ceremony on July 7, 1980. She was "nine months-plus pregnant" with their youngest child, Billy.
The town moved his swearing-in up to the start of the meeting that evening since Donna was in labor. Blessing was sworn in, and they quickly departed for the hospital.
"I was already in labor, but I refused to miss it," Donna said.
Billy was born around 7 a.m. the next morning. Blessing's family said such moments showed just how dedicated he was to both family and the police department.
"That's one of a thousand examples over the course of his life that just shows that balance of the commitment to what he loved job-wise and everything he loved police-wise," said oldest son, Steve Repetti.
Blessing retired from the Easton Police Department in 1995. He came out of retirement to serve as chief deputy at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, where he retired from in 2002.
Greg Wright, Easton's current deputy chief, was hired by Blessing in 1987. Wright described Blessing as a true professional and his "first cheerleader."
"He had a lot of respect in his agency and his staff," Wright said.
Blessing spearheaded the creation of an evidence collection unit and the modern-era bike patrol, Wright said.
"He really pushed the department to be bigger than what it was as he became chief," the deputy chief said.
Wright said Blessing had a significant presence in the community after his retirement as police chief. Blessing was "very proud of the people he hired, and more proud when they succeeded," Wright said.
Blessing spearheaded Talbot County's Drug Abuse Resistance Education program, which is still active within the sheriff's office today.
Outside of police work, Blessing was often recognized and respected walking around town or dining in local restaurants, close family said. This week, the family has heard from many in the community who were positively impacted by Blessing's time coaching soccer teams in Talbot County and at the Easton Little League.
A few years ago, Blessing was in Talbot Hospice after surgery, Billy said. The team at Talbot Hospice was "phenomenal," he added.
Blessing fought through his health conditions and returned home for around another 2½ years, a sign of his "tough" and fighting spirit, Billy said.
In addition to his wife, Donna, Blessing is survived by four children: Steve Repetti, Robin O'Brien, Stacie Johnson and Billy Blessing. He is also survived by seven grandchildren, as well as two great-grandchildren and one more on the way.
Stacie Johnson said she and Robin, both grandparents, are now singing the same songs to their grandchildren as their father did to them. Blessing's family said he was a great police officer, dad and husband — and especially an amazing grandfather.
"He loved the Town of Easton so much and was so proud to be the chief," Donna said. "His family was extremely important to him, all of his children and grandchildren." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a remembrance of a former police chief following his death, fitting the obituary category while also relating to public safety and local government.

title: From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy
author: Konner Metz
content:
From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — John North was more than just a well-respected judge.The former Talbot County state's attorney and judge of the District and Circuit courts wore many hats during his professional and retired life, serving as a protector of the Chesapeake Bay, log canoe racing aficionado and vintage automobile enthusiast.
In recent days, family, friends and the Talbot County community have remembered North for his roles in all of those capacities and more.
North died in St. Michaels on Sept. 19. He was 94.
Oldest son David North remembered his father as "competitive with compassion." He was supportive and thorough in everything he did, his son said.
"Right through the end, he was showing us how to have fun under not very good circumstances and how to stay competitive," David North said. "And how to laugh."
North was Talbot County state's attorney from 1962 to 1971. He then served as judge for 12 years in District Court and five years in Circuit Court before his appointment as the first chairman of the Maryland Critical Area Commission, the state agency responsible for protecting the health of the Chesapeake Bay and enforcing laws at a local level.
Pete Lesher, current Talbot County Council vice president, reflected on North's impact with the commission and as one of the founders of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in the 1960s.
"He lived and played on Chesapeake waters," said Lesher, also the museum's chief historian. "He valued the health of these waters and I think relished that role of caring for them in the capacity of the Critical Area regulation."
Ren Serey, former executive director of the Critical Area Commission, worked closely with North for many years. "The Judge," as North was widely known, brought the necessary judicial expertise and temperament to chair the commission, Serey said.
North was responsible for implementing local critical area programs at a time when the Bay's environmental needs clashed with rural growth and development patterns, Serey said. But North struck the perfect balance in adjudicating such matters.
"Having Judge North up there at the head of the table facing 29 people who were debating these issues was just the perfect role for him," Serey said. " ... He knew how to listen, he knew how to interject, he knew how to keep the discussion without certain boundaries."
Those that worked closely with North said he was widely trusted for his fairness and loyalty.
Lesher recalled a time in the early 2000s when the state committed funds for repairs to the Chesapeake Bay's skipjack fleet. But the state didn't fully lay out how the money would be doled out among skipjack captains in Tilghman Island and Deal Island.
Judge North, though, stepped in.
"Who was going to be the trusted arbiter if it came down to a Deal Island versus Tilghman Island? It was Judge North," Lesher said. "He was trusted by these watermen."
North's wife of 64 years, Ethel Towers North, died in 2019. He is survived by sons David and Daniel and their wives Joan Hoge-North and Margaret Enloe-North, along with grandchildren Drew North, Dylan North, Campbell North, William Spencer North and Nathaniel Vivian, and former daughters-in-law, Sallie North and Carrington North. He is also survived by Comber McHugh, a companion of later years.
In addition to his esteemed roles with the courts and the Critical Area Commission, North was a local log canoe captain. He wrote a book on sailing log canoes, which was published by the Maritime Museum in 2018.
"The Judge" skippered Island Bird, the 27-foot-4-inch log canoe built by North's great-grandfather in 1882.
David North said his younger brother Daniel took up his dad's sailing hobby. They both have kids who continue sailing on the Chesapeake Bay.
"It's a piece of our family. It's a piece of our heritage," David North said.
In his spare time, "The Judge" was a lover of feral cats, a keen reader and a sculptor. Some of his sculpting works are displayed at The Trippe Gallery in Easton.
David North said he followed his dad's footsteps in the world of automobile restoration and car shows. Judge North especially loved Bugattis and Duesenbergs.
North was a founder of the St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance, an annual car showcase nearing its 20-year mark. Luke Phipps, the festival's current chair, said it began as simply an oyster roast at North's house in St. Michaels, where friends of "The Judge" would bring their vintage cars to his front lawn. Then, the tradition grew into a solidified event.
The 18th St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance was hosted Sept. 26-28 at the Kent Island Yacht Club. Despite heavy rain the night before the festival's last hurrah on Sept. 28, Phipps said it was a "beautiful" and sunny Sunday.
Phipps said all he could think of was North — a close friend and valuable mentor — smiling down on Sunday.
He recalled North as a "sharp" and an "eloquently spoken" man.
"There'll never be another one like him," Phipps said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is primarily a tribute and death notice for Judge John North, fitting the Obituaries category, while also touching on his local government service, environmental work, and cultural activities.
